Atomic energy is not a reusable energy. With the help of reprocessing and transmutation, an attempt could be made to reduce the necessary storage time to hundreds of years, but the processes required for this are also under criticism and are not yet ready for application.

Sorry, this video gets an F for its superficiality and being merely a collection of faddish ideas like "soaking the rich" to pay for a new super grid, the effect of various programs, and I don't know where they got the idea that Green got cheaper than fossil fuels in 2018 (I sure didn't hear anyone trumpeting a momentous day in 2018 but the fossil fuel industry itself based on its own data announced that nexus occuring approx June or July 2021).

Let's put a stake in a few things mentioned in this video. Although this might in some ways agree with the fundamental message, is based on real facts rather than the loose and careless unsupported arguments floating around in social media.

1. The electrical grid will be expensive and can be paid for by soaking the rich. The new super grid which will be more efficient, reliable and transport electricity over longer distances can be and more likely will be paid for by MMT (Modern MMonetary Theory) practices such as borrowing from teh future. When infrastructre like a new Grid is considered, the benefits will be very long term, probably over 100 years including projected maintenance and management costs. It should also be recognized that the US grid is comprised of numerous private operators that will make individual decisions. The point is, funds will need to be made available on extremely long payment schedules, likely over 50 years. Although taxing the rich can and possibly should be discussed, it's not the way such things as financing a new electrical grid on a national scale should be financed.

2. There is no theoretical shortage of Green electricity to power the transition from fossil fuels to Green. The main problem for most states in the USA (and the rest of the world) is a lack of commitment to just do the transition. In the US, the entire West Coast is already positioned and is on schedule in its transition. Texas is largely powered by wind most of the time. The problem states are in the Southeast which still burn coal and have nuclear plants (which I don't consider Green, nuclear is a highly dangerous and posisonous solution that sells itself as being able to contain its poisons and isolate from the greater environment). California likely already has the capacity to support every local citizen owning his own EV car today if that magically happened. Already approx 30% of all its energy is sourced from Green and that's including at least about 4 hours of every day wasted generating electricity in the morning when businesses aren't open and people aren't fully awake. When and should California decides not to waste that energy and store it for use later that day, California will instancely add about another 30% Green electricity to being used. Other states can look at the California template and decide what can be used locally, California has all the facts and figures anyone would need to create a solution from practically any Green source and when a new supergrid is installed will meant that wherever energy is produced can be transported more efficiently to wherever it's used.

3. Yes, we are living through a kind of Industrial Resolution if you want to call it that. But, it has little to do with the Internet although the Internet has a lot to do with managing resources more efficiently due to this also being a revolutionary Information Age. We are also living in a unique age of human discovery and new understanding of everything around us including basic sciences. If anyone who went to college and graduated 60 years ago were to take another test today, I would guarantee that person would fail a basic test for today's version of those courses. Chemistry has changed. Physics has changed. Social Sciences has changed. Everything is radically changed more in the past 60 years than maybe the prior 120 or 200 years combined. This has everything to do with how we govern ourselves and make decisions because so many people rely on their personal and life experiences without considering that is all obsolete when making the best possible decisions today.

4. the Transition to Green has nothing to do with the cost of Green decades ago vs the cost of Green today. The capability of Green decades ago was also ridiculously poor so it wasn't usable no matter the cost. Similarly the technology we had then like energy storage (batteries) was so poor, we wouldn't eenn have mobile phones. There is a lot more to what makes today's evolutiona and revolution possible than the simple things described in this video.

I live in the Antelope Valley, which is a high desert area in Southern California.  I want to preface this by noting that I am for solar and have a solar system that powers my home.  With that being said, the solar farms that have sprouted around the high desert are astounding in both good and bad ways. It's great that they can generate so much electricity, but they devastate the local ecosystem.  From the front of my house, I can see the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains.  During late March and early August, those foothills would turn a beautiful orange, as the wild poppies would bloom.  Now, It's a sea of black solar panels.  A large portion of the wild life that used to live there is gone.  People think "Oh it's a desert. Nothing lives there" but that is totally wrong.  There is a large variety of wildlife, from coyotes, deer, bobcats & desert tortoises to a large variety of ground squirrels, quail, burrowing owls and hundreds of cold blooded species.  The majority of these creatures are displaced with these large, fenced off solar farms that can cover hundreds of acres.  The same goes for the wind farms that, while not as bad, still devastate the local ecosystem with all the access roads, buildings and cement pads that are needed for the thousands of wind turbines that dot the Tehachapi Pass.  We really need to focus on modern Nuclear power plants.

Management (or managing) is the administration of an organization, whether it is a business, a non-profit organization, or a government body. It is the art and science of managing resources of the business.

Management includes the activities of setting the strategy of an organization and coordinating the efforts of its employees (or of volunteers) to accomplish its objectives through the application of available resources, such as financial, natural, technological, and human resources. "Run the business"[1] and "Change the business" are two concepts that are used in management to differentiate between the continued delivery of goods or services and adapting of goods or services to meet the changing needs of customers - see trend. The term "management" may also refer to those people who manage an organization—managers.

Some people study management at colleges or universities; major degrees in management includes the Bachelor of Commerce (B.Com.), Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA.), Master of Business Administration (MBA.), Master in Management (MSM or MIM) and, for the public sector, the Master of Public Administration (MPA) degree. Individuals who aim to become management specialists or experts, management researchers, or professors may complete the Doctor of Management (DM), the Doctor of Business Administration (DBA), or the Ph.D. in Business Administration or Management. In the past few decades, there has been a movement for evidence-based management.

Capturing 1/100 of the energy the earth receives from the sun. Let's look at what that means.
1. First only half of the earth's surface is exposed to the sun at a given moment.
2. The theoretical limit (Shockley-Queisser limit) for solar cell efficiency is 30%.
3. Only 70% of the energy hitting the atmosphere reaches the earth's surface.
4. 75% of the earth is covered in water.
The first two items wipe out the 6 times multiplier of the example.
Item 4 means the amount of land needed is much greater than a whole earth calculation suggests by a multiple of 4. Item 3 means we need an additional 42% land surface (1÷ .7= 1.42).
The land area of earth is 57 million square miles. 57 million ÷ 100 × 1.42 = 809000 square miles of solar panels at a minimum for the energy required.
To put this in perspective of the resources required, it's estimated the about 1/8% (.00125) is paved, that is 71000 square miles, less than a tenth of the area for the minimum solar collection array.
Keep in mind these panels need to be near the equator to be efficient.
Imagine the mining requirements to provide the raw materials for this.

if every source of power generation in California currently available, solar, wind, Hydro, nuclear, natural gas, oil, coal, if every power generator was online and producing at the maximum, with none of them off-line for maintenance.. they could not possibly supply enough power to charge every car in California if every car in California at this moment was an electric vehicle. that means, no power for hospitals, schools, stores, water sewage and supply plants, police stations, malls, homes, home air-conditioning, traffic lights, none of them using power from the grid, all the power going to just charging electric vehicles if every car in California right now I was electric.. they can’t possibly meet the demand. I believe there is a future for electric vehicles. But..
60 Minutes did a report a few months ago about the Volvo making heavy equipment for mining those big trucks with those enormous wheels on mining sites, they made an electric one. Volvo now will not make that vehicle and here is why
The battery itself weighs 20 tons and only puts out power for 6 1/2 hours. Those companies need those machines to run 24/7 to pay for themselves. The recharge time on that battery is 36 hours..
Volvo has given up on the battery powered mining trucks and similar equipment. They are going to hydrogen. The future is hydrogen in Europe for power generation and for vehicles.
it’s nice to imagine self driving Tesla tractor trailers powered by electric. But their range is very limited, and the recharge time is very long..
there are literally tens of millions of mechanics in the world that are able to work on hydrogen internal combustion equipment because it is the same as internal combustion that runs on gasoline and diesel. Just a different fuel.
on the other hand, there are probably not even 100,000 mechanics around the world able to repair electric vehicles. It’s going to take generations to train enough mechanics to work on electric vehicles.

I think it’s a good idea to put solar panels on your roof and tie into the electric grid. You can go on the Internet and buy a 5KW battery backed up system for under $10,000, hire a registered electrician that will do the install correctly by going through the procedure of getting the proper permits and inspection and getting the permission and permits from the electric company. You can hire a registered electrician that will do it correctly, and a helper, for probably under $3000 to install that system..
for less than $15 you could be pretty independent of the electric grid.. it makes me cringe when I see people spending over $50,000 for solar rooftop systems, or having them installed “free “only to pay your regular electric bill to the company that installed it for free when you could have it installed for a fraction of that cost and it would pay for itself at least here in Pennsylvania where there is a law that the local utility must pay you $.12 per kilowatt of power you put back into the grid..
I am retired from an electric company. I did field investigations checking for tampering ECT. When I would pull up to a house that had solar panels, I knew instantly why we had been paying them instead of them paying us. It’s not a lot, one customer was paid a little under $600 for the total power that customer put back into the grid and paid us zero dollars that included certain charges that the customer must pay to the utility and to the state and taxes. The customer still made a profit of $600 with a 5KW rooftop system..
another customer had two separate 2 ton air conditioner systems, and a swimming pool with a pump that ran 24 seven for four months of the year. That customer was paid $50 by the utility and paid zero dollars for that year to the company for power. So that was a break even for that customer..
It would not be that expensive to add a few extra powergenerating solar panels and up your system to do something like 7KW. This would put additional power available for recharging your electric vehicle if you have one or intend to get one.. but keep in mind, those vehicles are worth less than a cost of a replacement battery after six or eight years..

There is only 50% of the planet facing the sun at one time, and about 50% of this has the sun at a low angle. Solar panels are not maintenance free and degrade over time by about 0.5% per year with a useful life of 25-30 years, resulting in recycling issues or simply to become toxic landfill. The current efficiency of solar panels is about 20% and about 70% of the available planet surface area is water. Cloud, dirt and shadows also have a negative effect. Do some math: 1000j/s = 1Kw, a 250w panel = 65in x 39in and work out how much area is needed and associated infrastructure.

Wind power is good if the wind blows, thus a stubborn high pressure system can leave a power deficit. Personal conversations with a repair technician reveal that they are prone to failure, expensive to fix and can only be repaired during calm weather requiring the use of 2-3 large cranes. Each turbine needs 2-3 tonnes of oil for the gearbox and the blades degrade over time requiring replacement of several tonnes of fibreglass which we haven't found a way to recycle. There is also the footprint of the towers and access roads. Offshore placement can provide habitat for fish stocks.

The raw materials (steel, concrete, copper, lead, plastics, aluminium etc) for these systems must come from somewhere as must the manufacture process, all requiring a viable energy source.

I am not against renewable energy, however it is not the wonder cure for the future. Hydro energy has served well, but even this has issues due to environment loss and flooding, placement of reservoirs etc.

I am of the opinion that if we want access to clean energy, then nuclear is the best option with Thorium showing the best safety margins, and coal fired power is an option for many who cannot afford nuclear as this will produce less emissions than burning biomass.

It will be interesting to see how the solutions for aviation and heavy transport pan out as battery power seems to be an issue here, particularly in remote locations. I don't see hydrogen being the answer due to the fact that it is energy intensive to create and expensive, then to safely store. Anyone remember the Hindenburg?

It is incumbent on us all to do our bit and help as many as we can while reducing emissions and waste, not make the rich richer and let the poor die. I hope this is not the agenda.

Comment number 20,529. What's the goddam point? This is all entirely wrong. Wind and solar are only cheaper than fossil fuels IN A FOSSIL FUEL ECONOMY. This may seem paradoxical, but consider the fact that the wind doesn't always blow, and the sun doesn't always shine. Even if you could build enough windmills, and install enough solar panels (and replace them every 20 years at similar or greater cost) to completely supply the world's energy needs, you'd still need to maintain a full fossil fuel generating capacity alongside that massive and expensive wind and solar infrastructure.
This cost is almost certainly not facotred in to the cost of wind and solar. Nor is manufacture of wind turbines and solar panels - nor the mining and processing of rare earth metals, almost certainly all achieved using fossil fuel energy. Less yet does this analysis account for the recycling of solar panels and wind turbine blades - because they are virtually impossible to recycle.
In short - all the heavy lifting is being done by fossil fuels, and only the last yard is being compared in favour of wind and solar, on the basis of commodity prices, and manufacturing costs set by the price of the fossil fuel energy required to develop them.

‘Lies’ is indeed the correct title! Never seen so much fiction. What about back-up, which is required 100% of the time because wind and solar go from 100% of generation capacity to 0% from minute to minute, and averages only around 30%? Alarmists never include that in the cost, but it actually means you need two energy systems side by side. And right now, battery tech is years from being up to the job, pumped hydro is unrealistic in most countries (and incredibly expensive to set up), while green hydro is a pipe dream (and a dangerous one). The ONLY back-up that works is gas. So renewables will only work if backed up by massive amounts of that fossil fuel. And then there’s the huge cost of building enough solar and wind farms, the cost of distribution from ridiculously widespread sources, the tech cost of dealing with the intermittence, and the environmental cost of the mining of the necessary minerals for renewables, especially highly toxic rare earth minerals. When all the sea ice melts, it will raise sea level by x number of feet.

There's that simply little sciencey thing called displacement. Fact. If all the sea ice melts, it will have zero effect on sea level.

If CO2 increased from 400ppm to 800ppm, it will only increase the average temperature by 1°. Not 2.5° to 3°.
To increase the average temperature 2°, the CO2 levels would need to increase to 1600ppm. That's not going to happen.

Geological history shows CO2 levels between 4000ppm and 6000ppm and the average temperature being about 10° higher then today. The dinosaurs did just fine. It's those rocks falling out of the sky you need to watch out for. Or super volcanoes like the 1 in Yellowstone.

During the mini ice age which ended at about the time of the industrial revolution, the average temperature was about 1° cooler then today. Obviously when a mini ice age ends, the temperature will increase.

Geological history also shows the average temperature has been higher a couple times in the last 2000 years and a few more times since the end of the last glacial period 12,000 years ago. We're currently in an interglacial period where the climate warms, but a 1000 years from now, we'll be going back into a glacial period. That's when half the world will be covered in 1000's of feet of ice again.

You are missing a lot.
1) Solar/Wind/etc 'Renewable' energy isn't anywhere close to actually being renewable yet - make it a closed cycle that takes only energy inputs from previous iteration and recycles at least 95% materials, and that would be close. As is, calling it energy conservables with mostly chinese fossil fuel and materials serving as input for panel/turbine/battery/etc production is more apt. Imo, the word 'Renewable' as used by media is just yet another attempt at Orwellian Newspeak.
2) Solar/WInd require ridiculous amount of energy storage capacity to serve as the grid backbone. If we tried to use lithium batteries as that, there is simply not enough lithium produced in the world within last decades (or next decades, assuming no revolutionary lithium production growth) to do so.
3) Countries in Europe near 100% reliant on 'renewables' are lie by omission - they simply use interconnections with other fossil/nuclear powered countries to compensate for intermittent nature of 'renewables'. This isn't a workable solution for the whole energy grid, only for small parts.

Can we take a step back, forget about the financial impact of renewables and focus on the environmental impact of gathering all of the resources required in the manufacturing, shipping, and assembly of the devices required for renewables such as solar panels? We also need to look at the availability of some of the resources which are required. If we want to push out renewables on the type of scale that is suggested, do we even have enough of all of the resources to manufacture enough devices to power the world?

The silicon used in the manufacturing of solar panels isn't just any kind of sand you find on the beach. It is a specific type of sand that must be used and the quantity is much lower than most people realize. It has to do with purity and shape.

In addition to that tons of CO2 are also released into the atmosphere by the equipment which is used for mining the resources (Silicon, Boron, Gallium, Phosphorus, Indium, Cadmium, Lithium for batteries, Copper, Lead, Aluminum, and many other necessary materials depending on the type of panel) and the transport of both raw materials and components. The shipping industry is responsible for a massive amount of pollution annually especially cargo vessels.

Then, the manufacturing process for solar panels requires coal, wood charcoal, and other resources as part of the process of creating silicon ingots. The temperatures that must be reached to purify the silicon require a huge amount of energy usually provided by coal power plants. The purification process releases CO2 into the atmosphere as carbon is removed from the silicon. More energy is needed to cut the ingots into wafers and dope them with the appropriate chemicals to turn them into semiconductors.

Then once they are created, shipped, and installed, if something like a hurricane, tornado, or other natural disaster destroys them before they reach that 30 year mark people always point at, you can't even recycle them. They can't even go in a landfill because they are considered hazardous waste.

I'm more concerned about the environment than the economical perspective, but a lot of people who think some of these things are going to save the environment are disconnected from the actual environmental impact of most renewables. Instead of concentrating the pollution to one or two locations (mining and power generation), we are spreading it out globally in the process of creating things we think will reduce the pollution because they don't generate CO2 while attached to your roof.

Nuclear on the other hand, is extremely efficient and has less of an overall environmental impact as long as it is managed appropriately. I'm very interested in the research associated with SMRs (Small Modular Reactors) because they have a smaller overall footprint, can be scaled for appropriate power demands, and use far less resources than all of the renewables currently on the market.

People act like billions of tons of nuclear waste are generated from the power plants, but that simply isn't the truth. The waste is far less than most people realize and if the US would update their regulations to match current technology, we could get more use out of the materials that are currently sitting right next to power plants that were stored as waste in the past. That significantly reduces the amount of mining that would be necessary to collect more material because we already have it.

Another technology that I think seems quite promising are the LNG collection plants that are using fumes released naturally in landfills as waste decomposes. That seems like a good use of something that is going to get released into the atmosphere whether we put good use to it or not. Might as well get something good out of the terrible mess we have already made by having landfills in the first place.

Sorry, but your ideas about taxation are very naive. The wealth of the ultra-rich is tied up in unrealized capital gains. Until they sell those assets there is no income which can be taxed.

So you say: "That's okay, let's just tax those unrealized gains"

But that is a terrible idea. Once you cede the government that power, the middle class becomes a juicy target. They are sitting on a collective fortune in unrealized gains in the form of their homes and investment portfolios.


But you say: "But the government would never do that!"

Until you've been bitten by the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT). A tax that also targeted the ultra-wealthy, but is now mostly paid by the middle class. You cannot trust politicians with this stuff or you will live to regret it.

As for corporate profits. Those are either invested back into the business or they are paid as dividends to the stockholders, who pay a 20% tax on that income. Companies also pay property tax, sales tax, half of their employees Social Security tax, etc.

It is a moronic left-wing fantasy to believe that companies don't contribute to our tax coffers.

The first time I saw a solar panel was in the summer of 1981,in the grounds of my secondary school. I thought: what a great idea,and how soon will it be before kit like this (more developed and advanced version) becomes widespread,given that our traditional resources like coal are finite.
But here in the UK at least,while the technology continued to improve slowly,the marketing side of the solar industry to the general public was unfortunately taken over by bands of doorstepping cowboys in the 90s and 2000s,or noughties if you like. That gave solar a bad name,to the fury of reputable providers and probably delayed the take-up as much as waiting for the price to come down. In the early summer 2005,while I was away for a month in the Far East,a wheelchair-bound chap I was a carer for was doorstepped by one of these people and sold a system with a single roof-mounted panel that turned out to be at least twice the recognised industry-wide price for such a system. It worked for about a year,then broke down. Upon contacting the company who sold it to him it turned out that they'd gone into receivership with a barrage of complaints about their activities. The engineers tried to help customers left high and dry,but the directors of the failed company were already in the process of setting up a new company - with another of those generic names they adopt involving words such as Smart and Afforable (🤣) so they could repeat the same wheeze on a still-too-unsuspecting public,its more vulnerable members not necessarily spared.
Had these kind of rip-offs not been allowed to ruin trust in the industry,and given a workable subsidy scheme perhaps,it could have been a fair bit earlier than the 2010s that solar panels on people's houses became a common sight.

I think you missed the biggest lie! That renewables can replace what we are using today with our current technology. The key issue is that they are intermittent. And thus they can only supplement the existing methods reducing the frequency of their use. We still must have them and must pay for their creation and operation. Until the storage problem is fixed, this line of thinking is dreaming. Utilities are starting to get enough users supplying power that they can no longer absorb the cost of operating as the renewables battery (by ramping production of mostly natural gas plants up and down). They are now forcing the solar users to pay for their grid use. Guess what, that "battery" is expensive and nearly equalling what they would have just paid for the power in the first place.

All these statements about converting to electric cars by some date are grossly optimistic. There isn't enough lithium available to accomplish it. It only takes some basic searches to verify it. Figure out how much a typical car uses (Tesla publishes this), find how many cars are sold per year globally. Multiply to get the total lithium need (just for transportation) and then compare that to the global lithium production rates. The number far exceeds what we currently mine. Now look at mining projections to see if we might catch up by the stated EV conversion dates. They still fall far short. And mining gets harder and more energy intensive the longer you do it because they mine the easiest stuff first.
There are some technologies that might relieve us from this problem, but are all experimental and may never plan out.

To be clear, I am all for green energy solutions, but a lot of what this video says is just moronic.

They mention capturing 1% of the sun's total energy like it should be feasible. It's not; not even remotely.

Amount of planet's surface covered by clouds at any given time: 67%
Amount of planet's surface covered by urban areas: 0.9%
Efficiency of solar panels: 18%

If you put those numbers together, even if you blanketed all urban areas on the planet (including roads, parks, and yards) with solar panels, you'd only capture around 0.01% of the sun's energy (i.e. 100 times less than what they are suggesting). This isn't something future technology is going to fix either; the theoretical maximum efficiency of solar panels is about 70%, which still would not get us anywhere even close to current energy demands.

Capturing 20% of the wind's energy is more laughably unrealistic. Wind turbines are only 20-40% efficient to begin with meaning you would have to cover THE ENTIRE PLANET (including oceans) with them to hit anything like 20%.

Theres a lot of things wrong with this. Firstly, the way you cite tax figures isn't really correct. Firstly, Amazon the corporation in the US actaully didn't make 11.2 billion dollars in profit. They paid 11.2 billion dollars to pay of debts and leases, which are not considered expenses when the debt or lease is obtained in the form of capital investment, which it almost exclusively is. This is where it gets tricky, the capital asset that Amazon leases annually is the intellectual property for Amazon and its various subsidiaries. A corporation outside the US owns all the non physical assets, and Amazon in America leases them from this sister company, which owes no taxes because it is somewhere else.

Interestingly though, this money isn't really used for anything. For other more complicated tax reasons, this pot of money parked off-shore is largely inaccessible. In many ways, its analogous to a Roth IRA, more than a tax cheat, in that while yes it does in fact reduce the total tax obligations of massively profitable corporation like Amazon, its also is both completely legal, important, and does still end up getting taxed, its just taxed differently.

The money in the offshore company can not be used to pay any of the corporate executives, otherwise it would be taxed as their income. If it was being taxed as their income, and Amazon had just paid it to them directly, it would still not have been taxed as part of Amazon's corporate profits, because paying your employees, including your executives is considered a business expense. The tax contribution would have been split, however, requiring Amazon to pay half out of its end of the nominal salary. From an off shore company paying a salary to an American citizen, it has no such obligation, and as such the executive in question is obligated to pay the full amount. This does not however change the amount of money that ends up in the executive's pocket, just how the accounting is done. Technically, it is feasible for an itemized deduction to include this fact that they were paid on a basis that required them to make the full income tax contribution (just like contractors, content creator, self employed and entrepreneurs) but ostensibly this just accounts for the fact that the nominal salary is just different from what it would be if the tax split was different. The valuable of the underlying goods and services is unaltered.

Instead, the offshore money remains in the tax haven until such time as Amazon has a use for it. Remember when I said that part of what Amazon is expensing includes the repayments of debts from capital investors? The largest capital investor in Amazon is ... Amazon. An incredible quantity of the money that Amazon scurries away at the end of every fiscal year is gradually amortized back to Amazon in the form of physical assets, expansion, subsidy, and investment from its sister company. What does Amazon pay in exchange for all this captial and intellectual property being dumped into it every year? Why their complete annual profits of course, minus whatever was scraped off the top to pay the employees, executives, loans, leases, maintenance, acquisitions, supply, distribution, and other tax obligations.

When Amazon "avoids" taxation by shuffling money around through various complex financial apparatuses, and disperses it into assets it has need or want of at a later date is a key component of its ability to maintain growth. There is no retroactive tax credit on profits if you eventually use that money to participate in a subsidized activity, or to expand your business. If your reinvestment occurs outside the current fiscal year for example, tough cookies. You either have to park those liquid assets in contracts or assets immediately, a process of "clearing" their books, or bite the bullet on a massive loss to taxes in which you will no longer be able to expand. This process of clearing books and parking assets is disruptive to underlying markets, creates room for corruption and fraud (it is precisely this process that is the basis of a great many embezzeling schemes) and exposes the company to all manner of liability and risk when its contracts fall through. Also, because these contracts represent guarantees on the exchange of goods or services yet to be provided, they technically are futures. This makes them subject to regulation by the SEC, further taxation anyways, and vulnerable to all kinds of market chicanery that ultimately erode or undermine the value of these investments in the long term, again crippling total capacity for growth.

While you may feel indifferent about the capacity for total annual growth or the effect asset circulation has in underlying markets, that's likely because you don't realize that every cent the government taxes from Amazons capital investment, dollars of tax revenue are lost in the subsequent years. Not to mention, dozens more dollars in income and commercial sales taxes, real estate. Then consider indirect contribution to national economic growth, the local consumer economies that power them, and the global economy that supplies cheap raw goods to our production. Those capital asset classes, especially real estate are also the bottom rung on the ladder of personal investment. The kind of price inflation and price insensitivity of companies pressured to park these assets would make them far less competitive, in much the same way that large employee insurance blocks drive up the price of medical care. The inflation of assets would make the National economy more fragile, and in the meantime price small time investors who's aggregate contributions are vital to strengthening it.

Your assertion that there is no problem with the "tax the rich" scheme (8:01), equating it to the 60's and saying "we did it before and everything was fine" is deceiving, inaccurate and untrue - so who is lying? You're not talking about the 'effective' tax rate. True we had economic growth in the 50's and 60's with higher tax rates. But you were also able to deduct almost everything on your tax return from your country club fee's to your credit card interest (and a host of other expenses). So the effective tax rate people paid (and the subsequent tax tax receipts) was actually much lower than the stated rates of the 50's and 60's. Historical data shows the actual tax rate PAID by the richest 1% of Americans in the 1950's was 42%. And that was for everything - all taxes levied including state & local, which means their actual federal rate was much lower.

Americans seem to believe that the Second Industrial Revolution (1870-1914) "mainly" only happened in the United States. Really, lol? 😅

"Fossil fuels have matured" is a lie. Even with the most innovative combustion engines today, 80% of the burnt energy of gasoline is wasted as heat. Just with cars alone, there are two technologies that would revolutionize the automotive industry: Ceramic Engines, and Camless Valvetrains.
A ceramic engine would be able to flip that energy waste upside down, meaning, it would use 80% of the fuel to actually do work, and only waste 20%. So you could theoretically get 3x as much efficiency out of the same fuel. Your Jetta that gets 40mpg could potentially be getting 120mpg on the exact same amount of fuel!
And Camless Valvetrains would completely remove all the inefficiencies of the modern camshaft. The problem with camshafts is that they are only able to have peak efficiency at specific RPM's, and the rest of it is wasted in unburnt fuel (that has to go and get burnt in a catalytic converter). Technologies like VTECH and VVT have gotten around it by having multiple cams and different profiles, but a camless setup would be electronically controlled to achieve optimum efficiency out of EVERY RPM. It would be a gas motor close to achieving the instant torque profile of an electric motor, for like 1/4 of the cost! and 1/4 of the current waste.
You could go one step further and perfect the CVT Transmissions, that allow a gradient of gearing, as opposed to the locked 5 or 6 speeds most manual transmissions have (or even the 8-10 speeds the most advanced regular Transmissions have).

All of that would continue to allow fossil fuels to blow ANY renewable out of the water, but it seems the industry doesn't want to bother, and would rather mine the shit out of African countries for their cobalt and nickel.

"Tax the rich sounds nice" until you really learn what it means and what it's results are. The proposed income tax does not matter that much to the already wealthy individuals or corporations. They can always lobby for exceptions, tax exemptions, loopholes and can afford to pay for entire divisions of people whose only job is to optimize their taxes. But even if there were no loopholes, no exemptions, nothing, it would punish most their competition. (both actual and potential) And last but not least, even if it all went down as well as possible, the only result would be them increasing prices for you, the final customer enough to pay for their taxes. One of the biggest renewables is Solar, but in today's market when you get solar for your home you do not get batteries to back up and retain power for a later time. In today's market you get solar based on your normal use and when the sun goes down you switch back over to your local power grid, So now your paying for the Solar you had installed (% based on your normal usage) and then you are paying for your local energy usage after the sun goes down. So is it really feasible to buy solar considering the pay back time is 10 to 20 years. The industry rule of thumb is if you use more than 20 KW hours per billing cycle then it is worth it, but if you do not it is not worth it. For me personally I would never buy solar unless I could use solar 24/7 with lithium ion batteries as a storage platform to be used during off hours like when the sun went down. Also one more piece of advice stay away from LP gas or just plain natural gas these two markets are non regulated and bill can vary by state a lot for example on month you could have a gas bill of $35.00 and the next you could have a bill of $95.00 this will all depend on the national demand for the product. But in other good news Electricity is regulated by each states local public utilities commission which over sees and regulates rates increases. Do not be fooled by media ads that say Natural gas is both cheaper and cleaner.  Anyway thanks for taking the time to read my post and I hope this information helps people out.

I'm not sure the falling cost of renewable technology is quite the good thing suggested. What it really means is that scale of production has allowed economies of scale, or, in other words, we are mining truly vast quantities of resources (not to mention exploiting people and the environment to do so). To date renewable energy has been a net addition to the globe's energy use (that is, it hasn't replaced fossil fuels, merely blunted the growth of their use); this suggests that humanity's impact in terms of resource usage is growing and we are simply taking the path of least resistance - imagining we can keep growing economies and consuming resources by wheeling in another energy source. The right solution is to massively reduce our global footprint, but how do we do that? Not easily and not anytime soon. In the meantime, wind and solar at scale appear to be a fool's errand.

First. Wind and solar. I'm not some paid fossil fuel shill that hate on wind and solar but to believe that these two things are the absolute way forward is naive and purely ideological. Both of these technologies require massive amounts of land to deploy, huge amounts of fossil fuels in order to mine, transport, produce, transport, deploy and maintain. Most estimates don't take this fact into consideration. This video also doesn't take into consideration the fact that these technologies are inconsistent. The wind doesn't always blow, the sun doesn't always shine. Fossil Fuels have lasted so long because they are cheap to deploy and they are consistent. Store it in batteries you say? This is also a less efficient way of doing things. Batteries produce heat when charging and discharging which is wasted energy on just that. Not to mention the large inverters that are needed to convert a battery's DC charge back to AC before being pushed to the electrical grid. Another huge inefficiency with more power lost to heat.

Wind and solar have their place and can make a huge difference in the future but if you're in the camp that we need to run our entire society off wind and solar then you need to do a bit more research because it aint gonna work brother.

Second. Nuclear power. I'm glad that nuclear at least got a mention in this video but it would've been better if they had gone into more detail with nuclear as nuclear is our current best option.

Currently not much energy is produced with nuclear energy in the US and that is just sad because nuclear, unlike wind and solar, actually has a small footprint, a fraction of the land use of wind and solar, and produces more energy more efficiently and consistently. Most of the nuclear reactors in the US are old and are really showing their age and our government through fear mongering and bureaucratic regulation have made it prohibitively expensive to deploy new nuclear power plants to the point that they are not even an option or economically feasible. Meanwhile the government spends money it doesn't have on subsidies for energy production that is less efficient and more destructive to the natural environment in wind and solar. If you aren't that read up on nuclear, consider looking up some videos on different types of reactors especially Thorium and other molten salt reactors. If you're worried about safety or terrorism, just know that more people are killed every year in fossil fuels and the deployment and maintenance of wind and solar than have been killed in the entire history of nuclear power including chernobyl, Fukushima and three mile island. Nuclear energy when deployed in smart, safe reactors is the safest energy production method in the world.

Three. Germany. While its true that Germany is reducing the amount of coal power plants this video skips over the inconvenient fact that the Germans are just buying coal produced energy from Poland and nuclear power from France while shutting down its own nuclear reactors. The video also fails to mention how much natural gas is being bought by Germany from the Russians. Oops.

Four. Tax the Rich. While the claim that Amazon doesn't pay any income tax is true, that is only because the video producer doesn't explain how these taxes work. Businesses are taxed on the profit they make but Amazon doesn't make any profit. They reinvest every penny they earn back into the business thus there is no profit to tax. This is how they do it. To suggest though that Amazon doesn't pay any tax is pretty misleading. Amazon has thousands of employees that all pay tax directly through the money that Amazon makes not to mention the shear amount of tax money generated through sales tax on the products that Amazon sells. Amazon is actually a huge producer of tax revenue for the government but I guess none of that matters if the money doesn't come from the top of the company to our stary-eyed progressive presenters. This video also mentioned how in the 1950s the top marginal tax rate was as high as 90%. This is also misleading. While its true the top marginal rate was that high, the top effective rate wasn't. Nobody paid those tax rates in the 1950s. If you made enough money to qualify for those rates, you just paid to have the tax code changed in your favor. I don't have the numbers off the top of my head but the effective tax rate was closer to what we have today anyway. This video is also misleading as to why there was such a boom in the 1950s where so much money was made. That has to do with the US being the only industrialized nation that wasn't bombed to shit in WW2. We exported millions of dollars of goods to Europe, Japan and other places that needed our goods to rebuild. There was also a huge labor shortage because of the thousands of men that died in WW2 that caused wages to sky rocket so bad that the government had to come in to cap wages so businesses wouldn't go out of business trying to over pay their work force. Those two things are why we had such tremendous growth. Not because of high taxes on the rich.

How could a large city operate entirely from solar energy, assuming they don't have enough wind for it to be reliable? A year or 2 ago, the upper Midwest in the US had below zero temperatures for 2 weeks while it was cloudy. Without doing the math, I would guess it would be impossible to store enough solar energy for the demand they had during that time. Natural gas is clean and can heat a home quickly. How large of battery storage facility would be required to store enough energy for that very possible scenario? I'm all for all types of energy and think the world's energy demands are met best with as many alternative sources of energy as possible. Why would you want to limit energy sources to wind, solar, and nuclear? There is a modern, clean, coal-fired power plant in Craig, Colorado that primarily emits STEAM into the atmosphere. It can provide electricity 24 hours a day, 7 days a week regardless of the weather. It is stupid to close a power plant like that just because someone is pushing solar and wind. It took a lot of energy to build that power plant. How many acres of solar panels would you need to replace that power plant?
My favorite of all, which is renewable, is nuclear power. Nuclear power can meet extreme energy demands and it has the smallest footprint of most energy sources. Despite the hype about nuclear power plant accidents, there have been few deaths from them. Chernobyl will never happen again. The nuclear energy program in the US is highly advanced and regulated. A lot of money was spent creating safe places to store nuclear waste. The accident at three-mile island in the Eastern US was sensationalized by the media even though nobody died from the partial meltdown. That was in 1979. Technology has advanced a lot since then. Studies showed that cancer rates didn't increase in the years following the accident.
My least favorite of the most popular power sources is wind energy. They require a lot of land area. They ruin the scenery in a large area; huge eye sore. They kill thousands of birds. They require a lot of maintenance. When Texas had freezing temperatures the blades froze and were damaged. In a beautiful, non-mountainous part of NE Colorado, the Pawnee Buttes (picture Dances with Wolves movie), a huge wind power plant ruins the view.
I definitely want the cleanest, most pristine environment that is practical to obtain. Anyone who knows me knows how much I love the mountains, forests, open spaces, and wilderness areas. I cringe at the site of Denver's "brown cloud" when I look east toward the horizon while hiking in the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains. I'm not an advocate for shutting down the country, but during the big shutdown for the pandemic, the brown cloud was gone. I had never seen the sky around Denver so clear. I also enjoyed hiking without hearing commercial planes flying overhead.
My bottom line is that we should use every clean source of energy to have plenty of redundancy so we don't have blackouts where people freeze to death or die of heat exposure. Modern coal and natural gas fired power plants are clean and efficient. Every source of power has pros and cons. I also realize there could be advances in any power source that makes it more attractive and viable. Location also makes a big difference, especially for wind and solar.

e) the role of electric vehicles —unless we are talking ebikes, emotorcycles and overhead powered rail vehicles— is completely overstated. Our urban spaces need to be remodeled to better accommodate pedestrians, bicycles and public transit (including overhead powered rail vehicles). This drastically lowers not just demand for fossil fuels but demands for energy and lithium. it is also just great for making urban places that aren't utterly miserable.
d) more demand shifting. if an electric vehicle needs to have 80 miles of range by 6 am, it doesn't need to suck down power at max charge rate as soon as it's plugged in.

c) more demand shifting, a lot of energy is spent on heating, but a lot of energy is also spent on space cooling and refrigeration also. Again, extra insulation reduces the peaks of those demands while thermal mass and having a thermostat that aims to keep temperatures in a range of values rather than at a single specified value can time shift demands to when supply is greatest reducing the need for explicit energy storage. Also, while resistors are often used for electric heating heat pumps are already used for cooling. Making those heat pumps reversible, at least the one used for space cooling, is just a couple servo controlled valves and a slightly smarter controller and is an absolute no brainer that makes for better heating. Using ground sourced heat pumps instead of air sources ones also is a significant energy saving. Also radiative cooling. Radiative cooling works the same way as radiative heating, just need somewhere cooler than what you're trying to cool off to send the heat. On nights with a clear sky, that somewhere is the 4 K void of space. See also: District Cooling.

b) no talk about alternative uses of solar energy other than PV. concentrated solar thermal electric power already beats the theoretical peak efficiency of single layer PV and it has built in storage; but solar hot water heaters and solar furnaces are far more efficient at providing hot water and space heating than powering resistive heating elements in electric hot water heaters and furnaces with PV. Ground sourced heat pumps can definitely reduce that advantage, which is also something not talked about.

a) no talk at all about demand shifting. a lot of energy is spent on space heating and water heating. With extra insulation the peak of those energy demands can be reduced. With a thermostat that aims to stay within a range of values instead of spot on a single value (so say 66-78 F rather than 72 F for space heating) and extra thermal mass when those energy demands occur can be time shifted to match when there is a peak in supply. Which can drastically reduce the need for explicit energy storage (heating your home above where you'd set the thermostat and letting things cool off throughout the day is a form of energy storage). See also: District Heating.

Honestly, the biggest lie about renewable energy (especially Solar) is that yes you're offsetting your power production during the day, but you're likely relying on dirty diesel generators or other fossil fuel driven power stations during the evening unless you have batteries on site at home to use the energy you made during the day.

Central plans that involve renewable energy are nothing short of shortsighted. The EU right now faces an energy crisis exactly because of this brainless push for renewables at all costs (where “all costs” means the decommissioning of nuclear and fossil fuel power plants). But the wind and sun aren’t always available and energy becomes scarcer and more expensive. Moreover renewables have horrendous EROEI figures. EROEI is an acronym for “energy returned on energy invested” and for renewables that is 1 unit of energy invested to get back 4 units. That’s just terrible! To give you a perspective a natural gas plant has an EROEI figure of 30 (!!) - 1 energy unit invested returns 30 units! Nuclear plants are even higher at 100. So renewables are wasting energy to be built, they have intermittent power producing properties and need to be backed by conventional power plants that are most polluting when they work intermittently themselves. A lignite power plant emits the most when in the warm-up phase not during its normal operation. With renewables not producing energy, literally half of the day, lignite plants ned to be cycled on and off and that’s exactly what you DON’T want to do with them. This is how Germany, the most aggressive country for the push of renewables, with 40% penetration, has managed to …worsen its air by adhering to solar and wind! Companies don't pay taxes, rather the people who buy their products (or services) do. It's included in the price. As far as Amazon in concerned, any profits made by Amazon were taxed through the taxes on the shareholders of Amazon stock. No, I don't think companies should pay any income tax at all.

As far as taxing the wealthy, they are already paying more than their "fair share". The top 1% of income earners in the US pay about 40% of all income taxes paid, yet they only take in about 20% of all income paid to individuals. The top 50% of income earners in the US pay about 97% of all income taxes paid yet they only take in about 88% of all income paid. The bottom 50% of income earners in the US pay about 3% of all income taxes paid yet they take in over 11% of all income paid. The average tax rates paid by these three groups is about 27% for the 1%, 16% for the top 50%, and 4% for the bottom 50%. (Source: IRS, Statistics of Income, Individual Income Rates and Tax Shares 2019).

I have some questions hopefully someone can help me with.

1. For nuclear power how do we overcome the fear of contentious nations claiming they are developing nuclear power instead of nuclear weapons... Iran, and N Korea come to mind.

2. Is it possible that in America the problem is size and that the voting may need to be focused on state government? Since we are so much larger than most other nations, and more complex (or convoluted perhaps) than nations like China with a strong central power base wouldn't that suggest that the solutions may need to vary by state or region based on their resources and population.

3. How do we keep these changes simple enough for them to actually work? For instance California has a large wealthy taxable population, but many are fleeing to avoid the idea of a wealth tax. They also are typically seen as one of the most progressive states but have the second largest carbon footprint, and as they shift power they have had some issues of power shortages which is why they are also the largest importer of energy in the country from other states, and Canada.

When we look at per capita Wyoming has the largest carbon footprint, but in reality almost half of thier energy production is exported to states like California.

Michigan and other states have cities like Detroit that would not benefit from the transition programs teaching miners to install solar etc... How do we help those who's jobs have already been phased out before this latest industrial revolution?

My questions all go towards the concept that perhaps we need to allow for unique solutions in different areas rather than a one size fits all solutiin like many smaller countries have been able to use. IMO the best way to get lawmakers who do what they were voted in to do is if they are more closely watched... aka local government. All of this goes to the idea that we may face bigger hurdles but maybe if we leap over the smaller ones first as individual states that we can compensate for areas with fossil fuel, and little motive to make changes, and other factors.

The oil companies do have a point about our grid not being ready. Our grid is not set up to handle such a huge influx of renewables yet. The grid was set up in the past to accommodate large generation sources (coal plants, natural gas plants, etc.) producing on the order of 600 to over 1000 MWs of power in few specific locations. New wind and solar farms have a lot more land requirements, and therefore are usually limited in capacity to 300-500 MW (a 200 MW solar farm is considered a LARGE solar farm - probably requiring about 1000-1200 acres of land). This means that a lot more solar and wind farms will will need to be built in different, distributed regions of the country to more efficiently deliver the power they produce to the end users.

The problem is that oftentimes these new solar and wind projects get placed in regions where the grid was not set up to adequately handle this additional generation capacity. Adding 200 MW to the grid is no joke, it can require tens of millions of dollars in transmission line and substation upgrades. Usually solar/wind project developers end up paying these costs to upgrade the transmission system when they apply to interconnect their new solar/wind farm.

I think a more probable solution is to have some federal authority/regulatory body take ownership of the national grid and regulate some of the processes related to generation, system planning, and network upgrades so they are at the same standard across the country. The federal government should really be the one paying these network and substation upgrade costs when new solar and wind projects are interconnecting to the grid. This is a huge barrier to new utility-scale renewable energy development and will continue to hinder progress until the federal government takes action.

There Is No Shortage of Energy; There Is Shortage of Normalcy

Despite increased production of energy from renewable sources, and despite the slowdown in car manufacturing, oil prices are skyrocketing. Even though fewer power plants still burn coal, coal prices are skyrocketing, as well. Natural gas prices, too, are going through the roof, and energy demand seems to outpace supply in every country and in every form of energy. Have Earth’s energy sources dwindled so drastically in a matter of months? The answer is a resounding “No!” There is no shortage of energy; there is a serious shortage of normalcy in human relations. I hope the current crisis will put some sense into humanity’s insane consumption.
The energy crunch indicates that we are over consuming. We are producing too much, throwing the excess production to the trash, polluting the ground, the air, and the water, and then we are complaining that we do not have enough. It is about as sane as killing one’s parents and then pleading for the court’s mercy because I’ve recently been orphaned.
It is time we reconsider everything we produce—how we divide production, profits, and goods, which services are necessary and which are redundant, and most importantly, how we treat one another. The goal of this process should be clear to everyone: survival.
There is no ulterior motive, no attempt to dominate or deprive anyone of power or wealth. It is simply that reality is forcing us to take all of humanity and the entire planet into consideration. If we don’t, our entire civilization will collapse like a deck of cards.
Since we still do not understand it and insist on running things the way we have always been running them—through power games—I anticipate a very cold and gloomy winter for the northern hemisphere. The energy crunch will leave many in dark and cold houses; there will be no gas for cars, and renewable energy will not replace traditional sources since there will be little sun during the winter. I hope that at least, it will make us rethink our values. If it doesn’t, next summer will be even worse than the awful summer that just ended.
I know that many people are counting on the promise of renewable energy to solve the energy problems of humanity. I think they are mistaken. There is plenty of energy, far more than we really need. We could cut emissions by at least half tomorrow. But the more we have, the hungrier we become, so our thirst for energy will never be satiated, and we will never stop exploiting the planet or each other until we reeducate ourselves and start being humane toward each other.
We have been behaving like spoiled brats whose parents buy them whatever they want. Now, our parents have run out of money and our childhood is over. It is time for us to mature and conduct ourselves like responsible adults, caring for all of humanity the way a mother cares for her entire family. If we think like a family, we will achieve normalcy.

There USED to be a lot of jobs in coal, but the vast majority of those was already lost a long time ago.
The difference: Back then lots of jobs vanished due to imports and automation. Companies had no problem with that because they could still burn just as much coal and make the same or better (due to not having to pay as many workers) profits. But now while there are far fewer jobs still to be lost, it’s the business with coal itself that is under threat.

All this is a deliberate attempt at inflating the (very limited) importance coal still plays on the job market in order to improve the negotiation position of big coal companies.

I'm pretty sure that cheap shot at Amazon will be left up at their whim. Amazon systematically reinvests its profits, meaning any profit estimate that you are using is misleading. A trillion dollar company making 10 billion dollars is within the error rate of estimation, that's the type of money they make in a big week.

The reason they don't pay taxes is because every country in existence taxes based off income. IPCC AR6 starkly warns the end of conventional farms, fisheries and forests if we do not act now:
1. Energy efficiency, 100% switch from inefficient fossil fuels by 2030. The more efficiency we manage, the more we can continue to do after 2030. 12%
2. Cut fossil extracts on emission paths 1% of today's level/month to zero by 2030. That means if there's something not yet transitioned, it must be shut off and lost. 80%
3. Drawdown, like 4 new trees/person/year (EG 1/American/month in USA). 3%
4. Ecosystem stabilization, like depaving, conservation, and restoring wetlands. 3%
5. Super-GHG reduction, like adding seaweed to feed to slow cattle methanogens, harvesting trees before they rot, refrigerant and foaming gas controls, and ending aboveground methane processing. 2%

So, you can have nuclear. It simply won't solve climate change, and won't avoid global climate famine.

A starving world will then be left to deal with the mess of nuclear cleanup.

Your tax ideas are economically illiterate and completely ignorant.

The most business-friendly capitalist jurisdictions in the world—Hong Kong and Singapore—offer all manner of social benefits for free or at steeply subsidized price, and they do so with lower tax rates than in America, and freer business environments. Singapore even spends a higher percentage of its GDP on defense than America and can still pull this off, easy. Many people are confusing welfare state benefits with "socialism", which are not the same thing. Socialism has to do with the socialized ownership of the means and resources of production, whereas capitalist welfare states rely on capitalist modes of ownership and production, with socialized welfare benefits subsidized through tax revenue. Totally different paradigms. Heck, even the Scandinavian welfare states are not only completely capitalist, they actually get higher rankings every year in their accommodation of entrepreneurship than does America. Ultimately where welfare capitalists and democratic socialists get things wrong is in their ignorance of what economist and money manager Nathan Lewis calls "the Magic Formula", namely: Low Taxes and Stable Money. Throughout history and up to our present hour and minute, the societies that achieved the greatest economic gains and including healthy government revenues for ample social spending were those that adhere closest to this Magic Formula.

PS: even a Libertarian luminary such as Ron Paul has gone on record making peace with the idea of the welfare capitalist state, in his case on condition that the US cease its overseas imperial adventures. That's a fair bargain in my opinion.

PPS: one reason why recent US tax cuts haven't benefited lower earners to the same extent as high earners is because of the US oligopolistic system and monetary chicanery. Inflation and loss of spending power of the dollar cause "tax bracket creep", where nominal incomes rise towards higher marginal tax brackets, but real spending power is declining or stagnant. Then, on top of that, many of the tax benefits are only able to be exploited by those having armies of tax accountants and attorneys using obscure loopholes and deductions (i.e. instead of cuts being easily accessible to tax payers across the board, including low earners, either through lowering marginal rates or significantly raising the brackets where higher rates apply). Finally, some tax benefits only apply to corporations and not individuals. For example US nationals and residents are taxed on global income in the year on which it is earned, with tax due being payable that same year. But corporations can defer tax on global income indefinitely, and only need to pay the tax due in the year that the income is repatriated to the US. Since corporations don't have a natural human lifespan and can last for generations, this effectively means that they can defer paying US tax on extra-territorial income practically forever if they so choose. This is a loophole in the law that is easily fixed, and doesn't require a high marginal tax rate to generate enormous tax revenue while still preserving a "business-friendly" tax environment (the low rate would be enough in itself to accomplish both goals).

It uses a common, but obsolete term such as green energy. Pollution in the form of water pollution has been responsible for killing plants, which are green, in the past. A lot of water pollution came from air pollution that would be washed into the rivers form rain. Acid rain from high sulfur coal burning was found to be responsible for killing much of the life in some lakes. Atmospheric CO2 is not in that category.

The fossil record indicates that during high levels of atmospheric CO2, as much as ten times todays atmospheric CO2 levels, there was likely higher levels of green plants around the world than today. Stating something is green when it it only reduces CO2 is not green. How plant growth in the oceans was effected is not addressed, but since a great deal atmospheric oxygen is produced from plant life in the oceans converting CO2 to oxygen and there are not signs of lower atmospheric oxygen, plant life in the oceans was likely different from today, but thriving.

Just because there is a large percentage of electrical power being produced by wind and solar doesn't mean these sources of electricity are eliminating the use of fossil fuel plants. In order to give base load electricity those sources of electricity are backed up typically with natural gas fired peaking plants. Since electrical demand has to be instant these peaking plants have to running even when they are not contributing electricity to the grid. They are burning fossil fuel even though they are providing no electricity.  The cost of solar and wind power is frequently stated as if a KW from these is same is the same as a KW produced as a base load plant and they are not. The cost of electrical power is dependent on the need to be able to produce electrical power immediately. When the real cost per year of solar and wind is calculated it is not competitive with fossil fuel plants.

Having to provide base load electrical demand from wind and solar is not possible without peaking plants or more recently the use of grid power storage batteries. Clean electrical energy means it is a smooth and constant voltage source which wind and photovoltaic panels can't provide by themselves. The use of expensive storage batteries for profitableBeyondcompetitivebiggerelectrical power storage batteries is that there can be little to no useful sunlight for weeks on end due to the smoke from forest fires and other photovoltaic panels disturbances. These may only happen once in a generation, but base load electrical power needs to be able to provide electrical power during these periods.


The chart showing a large leveling off of CO2 emissions stating this is due to renewables is wrong. It was the switch from coal to natural gas for electric power generation. In the USA during that period natural gas became cost competitive with older coal fired fuel plants around the mid 2000s for combined cycle gas turbine electric steam turbine electric plants. Even though the cost per energy unit was more for natural gas than coal, because the gas plants had efficiencies approaching 50% compared to older coal plants of around 25% they became basically same cost to run, but natural gas plants are much cheaper and faster to build.  

Then around 2010 natural gas got even cheaper. Only the most efficient coal plants were cheaper to run than gas turbine combined cycle plants. In 2016 or so natural gas had gotten so cheap it can be cheaper to use it instead of coal for creating steam for retrofitted older coal plants. Only the most compared

efficiency low emissions coal plants. They can also be placed in the middle of cities where the electrical demand is. . They require much less cooling water for their steam cycle than traditional coal fired plants because the majority of the power comes from the gas turbine. This drastically reduces the foot print of the plant without the need for large cooling towers. This makes them very attractive as long as natural gas cost remains low. By 2030 conditions may have changed where natural gas is no longer so cheap and due to its versatility in allowing combined cycle gas turbine plants near the center of electrical load there is no way to convert the electoral grid over to lower cost fuels. One source of electrical power that does address both emissions and base load requirements is nuclear electric power. It is currently not cost competitive with natural gas to build nuclear power plants and if they were built one of the new ideas such as thorium salt fission has claims of a much safer form of failsafe shutdown due to cooling system failure than the current nuclear electric power plants and less toxic nuclear waist.

Taxing the rich: Yes we need money to run are governments and services; however, private investors are more efficient at creating wealth. If the money is taken from the rich that means the way it was being used before is now starved. Doing this change suddenly would likely lead to whole industries going bankrupted.

Income tax of corporations: The primary tax on individuals is income tax and some capital gains (most stock investments). I don't think comparing a corporation income tax with individuals income tax is a fair comparison. The tax structure of a corporation is very different from that of an individual. Corporation pay a great deal of tax other than income tax.

Your innocent ignorance also shows in your comments about taxing corporations. Corporations are even more mobile than persons in getting their revenues into the most advantageous tax jurisdictions. Further, your claims regarding "corporations" not paying taxes are generally untrue.

Large corporations are often publicly held. Dividends associated with equity ownership through stocks are often taxed as ordinary income. Capital gains tax is imposed upon any gains made through the sale of stock; and short term capital gains tax rates are high. Large corporations often avoid the primary tax on their revenues because government grants tax rebates or legislative loop holes to them in exchange for . . . . . . . wait for it . . . . . . . political donations to the campaigns of those elected to tax them. . . . LOL. . . Boy, did you guys grow up this innocent, really?

Smaller corporations are often privately held. As such their revenues are generally reported on personal tax forms where they are taxed. And, believe it or not, the aggregate amount of revenues earned by all such small corporations far exceeds the aggregate amount of revenues earned by all such large corporations. Consequently, "corporations", in general are NOT dodging much in the way of taxes.

Nevertheless, you wanna impose some sort of "tax them - not me!" income tax surcharge on small corporations? Well, they can disappear from your State just as fast as those millionaires did from Maryland! (See below.)

If we're being science based, then comparing energy potentials of nuclear against wind and solar is like night and day. Nuclear is a constant, zero emission energy source that has magnitudes higher output that can legitimately power our societies...and largely able to do this in any environment.
Wind farms are impractical to build in many places where the air pressure isn't fluxuating enough to drive the turbines to make any appreciable power.
Solar energy suffers a similar fate. Many places don't get enough direct sunshine to properly optimize a huge solar panel array.
Also, I might add that solar arrays and wind farms share a common hang up that is extremely problematic; it's their footprints.
The kind of solar and wind setups that are of a scale to produce a decent power output take up an enormous amount of space.
Maybe this is ok for some massive solar array in a Nevada desert, but if it is needed in more habitable environments then acres and acres of land must be cut down and cleared out to make way for these.
Perhaps when we are able to launch solar arrays/reflectors as satellites, then that would give us some serious access to the tremendous energy our Sun has to offer us. Until then, our current photovoltaic cell technologies and methods are only capturing an unbelievably small fraction of a fraction of the Sun's energy.
Until we colonize space or find a stable method of commercial fusion energy, the planet's best hope for leaving the fossil fuel era as efficiently and responsibly as possible is nuclear fission reactors.

I think we can use ram pumps to solve the energy crisis. First we build a hollow cylindrical tower out at sea, to a depth of say 1100m. The tower is open to the air at the top and has a sealed base at the bottom. We drill a hole about 20m below the surface and feed water into the tower. The water falls down a pipe for about 200m where it powers a turbine that is connected to an electricity generator. We collect the water and drop it down a pipe for another 200m to another turbine. We do this twice more until we are getting electricity from four generators.
We then drop the water another 200m to power a turbine which drives a cog that is geared to turn a disc at the base of the tower. The waste water from the last turbine starts to collect at the bottom of the tower creating a shallow reservoir that we need to pump out.
The rotating disc at the base of the tower has cams along its edge. These cams are used to push pistons outwards. These pistons are in cylinders built into the wall in a circular formation. The cylinders are sealed at the interior side apart from where a piston rod enters to push the piston outward. The outside of the piston head is exposed to the deep sea water.
The cam will push the piston outward against the high pressure deep sea water. An inlet pipe will take water from our shallow reservoir which will be pulled into the space created in the cylinder, behind the piston head. When the cam releases the piston, the low pressure water inside the cylinder will be the only thing pushing the piston out against the high pressure deep sea water.
This is when the system acts as a ram pump.
The piston will be forced inward and will force the low pressure water back out through the inlet pipe toward the reservoir. The inlet pipe will now act the same as a waste pipe in a ram pump and the flowing water will shut a waste valve. The remaining water in the cylinder will be forced through a check valve into a pipe and upwards to the surface.
The larger the diameter of the tower, the more cylinders that can be built into the wall at the base of the tower.
I realise that the ram pump cylinder will pump more of its water back into the reservoir than it sends to the surface but we can always add more cylinders to the system. We can even put another layer of cylinders above the original ones as ram pumps still work underneath shallow water.
I think we should be able to pump water upwards at the same rate that it falls into the bottom of the tower and so keep the reservoir nice and shallow.
Now, if I understand the maths correctly, we might only be able to pump the water near to the surface. In that case, we can pump the water into a reservoir tank (inside the tower) and use the electricity generated by the first turbine to pump out the tank.
This will leave us with 3 generators worth of electricity for every tower built.

Summary: solar panels heat the planet, reflective roof coatings cool the planet.

Solar panels contribute to global warming, and thus are not green. "Huh!??", you say. Yes, it's true. Solar panels have a reflective index around .02 to .04, about the same as water or black asphalt. That means that only 2 to 4% of the sunlight that falls on them is reflected back into space, and thus lost to the earth's energy accumulation from the sun. The rest is either converted directly to heat, or electricity that will be converted to heat when it is used. So, if a solar panel is placed on a surface that has a reflective index greater than .04, it is warming the earth more than the original surface. According to Berkeley Laboratories, the average roof in LA has .17 reflectance. Concrete ranges from .35 to .50. All those people with solar panels on their roof in LA are actually heating the earth, and contributing to the urban heat island effect. Contrast that with a reflective roof coating that has a reflective index of between .8 and .9. If the area that was covered with a solar panel is instead coated with such a reflective coat, it will decrease the solar heat accumulation by over 70%.
Now that's green, unlike solar panels.
