Something also completely ignored in this video is the environmental impact of all those renewables.

Hydro is clean and cheap, but doesn't work everywhere since it needs a relatively steep valley. But most importantly, it floods vast amounts of very valuable river valley eco systems. And if water runs out due to drought (like what's been slowly happening at hoover dam), your dam stops working.

Solar requires vast, VAST amounts of land area and in doing so destroys vast amounts of eco system too. Even in a desert, there's valuable ecosystems that are destroyed when a solar plant is built. Solar is perfect though to integrate into existing cities and existing building roofs.
There is currently no plan at all to recycle solar panels when they break or reach the end of their lifespan in about 20-30 years (solar panels installed in the 90s are already at the end of their life). They contain vast amounts of toxic materials and rare metals, but currently were just dumping them in poor countries along with the rest of our electronic waste.

And wind also requires vast amounts of land area, although the impact is less. But they can be really noisy, and they are incredibly dangerous to birds killing indiscriminately, including rare or endangered species. On top of that, wind is very dependant on, well wind, producing next to nothing on still days, and massively overproducing on windy days. Although this last one could be solved with a smart grid.

By the way: It is also not true that solar panels on houses are efficient. They are extremely expensive compared to what they produce. The need subvention by tax payers or people not going to by them and since the subvention was cut over here in Germany the number of people putting solar panels on their roofs have dramatically decreased. But besides of the subvention by tax money paying for installations also the price for energy increased dramatically, since the mix of private produced solar energy makes managing the grid more expensive and everyone who uses energy pays for that as well as for the subvention of installing solar panels in the first place. So everything has become much more expensive on behalf of everyone, but the percentage of energy produced increase only by a tiny amount in fact. This is why politicians over here in Germany now try to focus more on wind turbines. But there is sadly also an issue with that, since building them is also very expensive, tax payers pay for the energy they produce extra and tax on that 'extra' (both by law for both wind and solar). At the same time we import more energy than ever before, since wind and solar can not produce the increasing demand caused by mass expansion of 'internet of things', electro-mobility and the growth in mobil energy for computing devices like even ever more mobile phones, tablets and so on. We have the highest demand in energy ever while the demand by 'production industry' hardly changed.
I am for an change, since I know we cannot not continue like we did in the past, but with what is done right now about 'climate change' and 'green deal' especially in Germany, but also in other countries, is obviously the completely wrong way and is about to make things ever worse. Yikes that part about the rich and big companies and taxes left a lot out. For one thing, in 2018 the top 10% of earners in the US ie the richest 10%, paid 71% of all income tax. Is that a fair share? As for big companies like Amazon, what they actually pay in Federal income taxes is a lot more complicated than simply saying 0%. A company as big as Amazon follows the income tax laws that have been on the books for years. Seriously Google it, let me know if you understand it. Between State Taxes, Payroll Taxes and the Sales Tax that they collect they pay or collect for the government in sales taxes a few Billions. The current corporate tax rate in the US rose to 28% under Biden from 21% under Trump. All in all Amazons income tax rate after whatever (legal) reductions they took advantage of was 1.3% which is pretty low to say the least. But not 0%. Anyway, I just get annoyed by misinformation. As for the ridiculous tax rate of the 1950’s being like 90% for the top earners I still have to research that but I have a feeling that to implement the same thing in today’s economy would not have the same effect of huge growth since the world was a totally different place then. For one thing the US was pretty much the biggest in terms of industry since we weren’t bombed to hell during WW2 unlike nearly every other industrialized country. How do we stay competitive with say China when we tax our industry at 90%? Maybe we can, I’d like to know how that would work.

Finally the point of tax incentives in the tax law is to increase growth and innovation. So, we want to stimulate the growth of Green Energy, will we be taxing those industries at 1950’s rates too? Why not, what’s good for Exxon and Amazon ought to be good for Green Tech too right? How are they supposed to grow at the rate that will reach our goals for America’s energy future if we don’t offer tax incentives that will effectively lower their income tax rates? I’m not saying that taxes are bad but there has to be a balance between what allows growth and what stymies innovation, or worse pushes companies to take their money elsewhere. That’s what ruined the US industry in the first place and why it went to China. When it’s more profitable to set up shop in Malaysia because US tax laws are too harsh, then, bye bye big industry. Big Corporations have to pay their Fair Share of taxes, the operative word being “Fair” that’s what is under debate.

It felt like the video oversimplified its approach on the challenges of renewables.
1. It talked about the solar and wind energy potentials in their totality without emphasizing that NOT all this energy potential is spread evenly geographically and in fact is relatively inaccessible to the areas where it is needed the most like population/industrial centers.

2. It focused on the harvesting technology becoming cheaper & efficient which is a fair point but ignored the ENERGY TRANSMISSION challenges altogether which is vital because most of the areas where you are harvesting renewables are remotely situated (deserts, shorelines, windfarms, etc.).

3. It talked about the advances in energy storage but conveniently ignored a lot of evidence that energy density stored in fossil fuel and nuclear energy are still far superior to whatever current battery technology we have today AND the latter are far more reliable all year round compared to the former since it can be stored idefinitely. The video also seemed to also be selective in statistics its showing to prop up battery technology advances. Kind of misleading.

4. While renewables are indeed advncings, they are nowhere near the scale that they can be relied to take on the base energy demand in any country. The statistics in the video itself where pretty telling of this.
Even the European countries the video cited still rely on fossil fuel and in some cases nuclear power to carry the base load of their respective countries. AND they still NEED the conventional power sources to get them through intermittent periods like winter.

The reason you cannot have Nuclear, Wind and Solar as your only (or even primary) energy sources is a simple study in supply and demand. You cannot control when you get the best supply (sunny or windy days) and Nuclear cannot scale up or back fast enough to compensate for higher or lower production times from the other two. You would need to essentially build large reservoirs to pump water up hill during high energy days and then release it over a turbine to recoup some percentage during low production days. This is economically infeasible for a host of reasons. And while the problem with energy shortages is apparent, the problem with more than needed is not always so obvious. Long story short, it damages the grid and is highly costly. The interesting thing is that energy demand usually peaks at night as people return home from work and begin to use their AC/Heat...while Solar is producing 0%. GG. Lastly, please review Sweden and what happened with they taxed Volvo, IKEA and SAAB like this. They left. This is the same thing happening to big tech in California right now, as they move to Texas for the 0% income taxes. It's also really disingenuous to say they pay no taxes, as they do this by utilizing deductions that anyone can do -- and they still pay more in payroll taxes in one year than one can conceive conceptually. On an individual level, it will cost you about 9,000USD but you can forgo your American citizenship and move abroad. Switzerland will happily allow you to negotiate into the 15% tax range. Other Billionaires like Peter Schiff have already moved to Puerto Rico to maintain their citizenship while paying 0% Federal Income Taxes (USA Territories).

I'm not in the industry myself; however, several family members are. They will happily tell you that energy companies want to supply you with cheap and reliable energy. They want your business and at a good profit margin. If these things were cheaper, more efficient and more profitable -- they wouldn't lie to you about it. They would change their business model. Oil and Natural Gas have had tumultuous gains and losses over the years - and energy companies would like to have a more stable priced item if they would. As far as the post tax benefits you discussed,. they are largely based on losses, which any business can do.

Lastly, Texas is something I am intimately familiar with. I live here obviously, hence the screen name. We build wind farms not because they are economically profitable but because they are politically profitable. We only get back about 85c for every $1 our citizens pay the Federal Government, so when Washington says "we will give you more money for wind farms" we say yes. And sure, they generate electricity - which we get keep because we have our own grid - but we have had to build a shit ton of Natural Gas power plants to ramp up during cloudy days or during less windy nights. Meanwhile, the TAXES ALONE paid to the State of Texas by Natural Gas and Oil production tops $2 Billion Dollars per year.

The strong economic growth in the US during the post WWII era, even with a very high top marginal tax rate, was substantially boosted by being the only major industrial power to come out of the war economically intact and highly enriched. Europe, Japan, China, and other competitors had massive rebuilding to do.

Today the US is gradually falling behind, overall (albeit mixed), with the rest of the world becoming ever more competitive. Expecting that a high tax rate will be just as easy to shrug off in this era as it was back then might be an enormous risk. Perhaps it's worth it, but this is not a slam dunk decision as presented.

The other problem is the idea that we can grab free money by taxing corporations. Overall, what happens is that if the corporation manages to sustain itself it must pass on that tax burden to its customers (it will not, in the long run, come from the shareholders) through price increases. One problem with that is that it's kind of regressive cost which hits the poor more than the rich (in terms of relative burden; the rich will of course pay more in absolute terms). It's not free money, it's just sneakily taken from the economy through hidden price increases - but a trillion dollars extracted from corporations and passed on to customers still takes a trillion dollars out of their pockets - but without progressive adjustments.

While I am concerned about possibly over-doing it, I like explicit and progressive taxation versus regressive taxation hidden in price increases (get less for your money).

There are other pros and cons to corporate taxes, besides this; there are some good reasons to support corporate taxes. But the idea that it's free money because it's paid by rich corporations is populist misinformation.

The three biggest flaws of "renewable" energy are as follows,
1. They're not green to make. It takes hundreds of tons of steel, carbon, copper, rare earth metals, and toxic chemicals to create wind turbines and solar cells. These are mostly produced in China in factories that have no pollution control standards whatsoever, and are powered by coal-fired plants that have no carbon-scrubbers. So in effect, you are not any more green for having bought so-called green power technology from a country that hides how much dirty energy they had to use to create it to sell it to you.
2. They're not green in operation. Due to their extremely low energy density (meaning ratio of land necessary to operate them compared to amount of energy produced), they require hundreds of acres in large farms to produce electricity. This is not eco-friendly to local wildlife, forests, or prairies that have to be cleared away to make room for them. Likewise birds have been hit by turbine blades and roasted out of the sky by mirrors that collect sunlight to focus it on solar cells in a central tower, and neither of these technologies discriminate in favor of endangered birds.
3. They tend to fail when they are most needed. During winter storms, the sun doesn't shine, and the turbines often either freeze or break down due to frost damage. This is the time where these technologies are needed most, and they typically either do not operate, or the power demands skyrocket (heating takes a lot of power) far above the measly quantity of electricity they can generate.

Let’s say you wish to replace a 1Gw nuclear plant with wind power. Let us go through the numbers. Many French reactors have a power level higher like 1.6Gw = 1600 mega watts. We’ll use 1Gw = 1000Mw to keep our arithmetic easy.
A 1 Gw nuclear Plant has a capacity factor or 95% some are higher some lower.
Wind Power has a capacity factor of 33% this can very as low as 25% or a bit higher.
For the layperson this may not seem so important so please bear with me. Because we wish to replace a nuclear plant with a wind farm
To build a wind farm you will need 1Gw/ 33% = 3Gw of power because of the capacity factor. The wind blows 33% of the time. That means 3Gw of power is needed to be produced power so to replace 1Gw of Nuclear. How this is done is wind supplied 1Gw of power to the grid while the remaining 2Gw of power goes to storage. So lets say we have very very predictable power where every third day the wind is blowing and at sufficient speed >20km/hr. So Monday it blows Tuesday and Wednesday the wind doesn’t blow. So on the Monday 1Gw goes to the grid 2Gw goes to storage to be used on Tuesday and Wednesday. Then by some miracle the wind blows on Thursday and the cycle continues… For EVER. If there is no wind power on the third day your out of luck. Now let’s calculate the size of the battery. Energy is power times a unit of time.
1 Joule of energy = 1 watt for one second. Therefore 2,000,000,000 watts (2Gw) needed to be stored in one day or 24x60x60 seconds= 86’400 seconds. So the storage that’s needed is 2,000,000,000x 86,400=
172,800Gj of energy storage. But the kicker here is assuming 100% storage capacity efficiency. Now let’s calculate the cost of 3Gw Wind plus 172,800GJ of energy storage.
Wind’s cost is about $1000 per Kw or $1 per watt (a low value). So 3Gw of wind will be $3 billion.
Batteries are about $500 / Kwh or (1Kwh = 1000w/K×60 min/hr x60 sec/min)
So that’s $500 / 3.6 million joules. Or .0001388889 $/J
Therefore 172,800 Gj x .00013888$/J= $24 billion
So that’s 24 plus 3 = $27 billion to replace 1 nuclear plant. So the cost of storage is the kicker.
But for how long?? A nuclear plant can go for 40 to 60 years.
For a wind farm its life could be 20years. So look to spend 3 $billion times 60/20 (or $9 billion) to cover replacement over 60 years. For batteries lithium ion type they can take 300 to 500 charges. For calculation lets use the generous 500 charges. If the batteries will be charged once every 3 days that’s 1500 days of life.
1500/365= 4.2 years Therefore over 60 years the replacement is 60/4.2= 14 times
So the total cost over 60 years is $24 billion x 14 for batteries plus $9 billion for wind turbines equaling a grand total over 60 years to be 24×14+9=

$345 billion. Over 60 years.

A cost that is not calculated is not just the cost per Kwhr or replacement costs over 60 years.
But the cost of a power failer.
The cost of a power failer is extremely difficult to calculate. A good example is that of a bakery or other industries that are highly dependent on reliable power. Bread that does not rise or a process that’s time dependent like the refrigeration of food or vaccines. A patient on an operating table. A person stuck in an elevator etc etc.
Now do the same for solar but it has a capacity factor of 20% less in Germany.
1/20% =5Gw etc etc. Create your own spread sheet and adjust some numbers if you like.
For nuclear it is 95% Do the math for it as well. You will need 0.05Gw of storage but this could be made up with natural gas. A lot of nuclear power plants have 2 reactors. Darlington 4 Pickering 8. Thanks. I almost didn't click to watch as I suspected that this was going to be some Q Anon type nonsensical anti renewable/anti climate change spin. But, as I have been involved with renewable developments in excess of 7 GW, I decided to try and educate. No need. (caveat; Renewables are generally sold on what are called Power Purchase Agreements and since about 2016, they have been on par with, or less than the cheapest coal and far less than LPG or Nuclear.
I will add that there are hurdles like getting energy from the resource location to the end user is a major issue, but we are tackling that. Also is the need to increase storage to replace the LPG Peaker plants. Storage tends to be quicker and far more efficient, but most utilities are in the middle of 20 or 30 year contracts that pay Peaker plants to stay running and then pay for fuel as needed. So, while the cost of electron or watt is higher, the base cost is a fixed contractual obligation and the only addition for required generation is fuel cost. Going forward, storage is far better, and there are ways out of the contracts, but...in many cases, these Peaker plants are subsidiaries or sisters to the utility so there is little incentive to shoot their own feet.

I'm a fossil who first got really interested in alternative energy back in the early 70's during the Arab oil embargos. The government jumped in and gave tax breaks, etc. for just about anything with the word "solar" in it. The upshot was a lot of junk. I still occasionally see houses with non-functional tracking solar arrays on their roofs, arrays dating from that dismal experiment. And then there are those "walk in solar collectors" that people tacked onto their houses. They generally didn't even make decent "sun rooms." We still have some residual silliness in the form of the "energy star" rebates. Others have taken on the absurdities of that program (just about anything can virtually automatically get the rating with little actual effort to substantiate claims. That star seems to be more of a "participation trophy"), so I only mention it here. The bad actors are still popping up. A retired neighbor made a major investment in solar a few years ago. Three years later she had to have all the panels replaced at her cost. The system had already failed and the supplier had magically shed any responsibility by exploiting incorporation laws.

Upshot:
1. I like the concept of "alternatives."

2. Having the government magically create money to fund alternative energy is a major mistake. The charlatans will pillage, the people are fleeced, and the energy goals are not truly met. Don't believe me about pillaging charlatans? just look at what is happening with Covid-19 aid: The enhanced unemployment payment fraud, the PPP fraud, etc. Nearsighted greed is always ready and able to exploit anything that sounds worthy. Plan for it.

3. If alternative energy solutions are going to work, they must be economically viable. Do not push money at alternative energy products. Instead, make alternative energy products that attract money. They must stand on their own economic feet. This requirement will weed out most of the junk.

4. Want government intervention? How about fixing things like incorporation laws to prevent repeated "duck and run" tactics. If the provider knows they cannot duck responsibility they might be more careful about providing robust, reliable products. And while the legislators are at it, please plug the money transfer policies that allow moving profits (often in the name of "business expense") to more favorably taxed entities.

5. Want more tax money? Well, the USA is so far in debt (on a per-capita basis) that there is no chance of paying it off. Asking for more government money amounts to "add another shift for the printing presses" and "sell more bonds to foreign nations" to further undermine our self-determination (Carl Marx was right: A capitalist will sell you the rope that will be used to hang him). As for "tax the rich," your words betray your economic ignorance. They don't have money sitting around in bags waiting to be handed out. The majority of the money is working in investments. The IMF study you (and many many others) cite is incredibly flawed. Here's an objective analysis of the fossil fuel subsidies they calculated for Canada:

Only 3% was actual subsidies, and most of that is in the form of tax breaks, not direct cash payment. Almost half was attributed to things like traffic congestion, accidents. They could have calculated the marginal emissions reduction of if we switched to an available tech like electric cars, and incorporate the $ value of that difference, but they didn't. Calculating $ value damage of global warming is a pretty sketchy science to begin with.

I'm wondering why the Shockley–Queisser limit was not addressed. The Shockley–Queisser limit states that solar cells are limited to being about 33% efficient. The best cells now are about 27%, so we are getting close to this limit. I hear claims of future great advances in solar energy efficiency, but I don't think we can get them based on the science behind the Shockley–Queisser limit. There is research ongoing about ways to exceed the Shockley–Queisser limit, but so far, no luck on that.
Shockley–Queisser has been around since the early 1960s and has yet to be disproven, so it is pretty sound science.

To be objective, they should have at least addressed this.

Saying that taxes in the 1950s and 1960s exceeded 70% on the wealthy is a total misnomer. In reality, not a single person back then paid anywhere near that much. Why? Those same decades were also the golden age of tax write-offs, a time when everything could be written off your taxes. So in actuality at the time, few people even paid 50% tax and absolutely no one at all paid more than that. In fact, it could actually be argued that the strength of the economy at the time was a direct result of the tax deductions, not the tax rates. At that time, the government gave huge incentives for wealthy to write off everything possible, from lavish dinners & vacations & flights to extra cars, boats, needless construction projects. Basically, if you could imagine something to write off your taxes, during that era, you could write it off. So companies & wealthy individuals had a huge incentive to spend far more than they do today. And it worked. The point I’m making is that there actually isn’t a need to tax the rich at a higher rate. Rather, all we need to do is get them to spend more or get them to actually pay the taxes at their current levels. After all, it doesn’t matter what tax rate you throw their way if they can just write it all off until they pay $0, which is exactly what Amazon and many other companies did. A simple solution is to force companies to pay a 5% gross income tax pre-deductions. That alone could actually provide the money needed for these infrastructure projects.

Interesting video. I just have a few questions/statements that weren't covered that I would like to point out.

Let's start with energy storage. Though solar and wind are decent sources of power, they are terrible at storing energy. Example, you only get power from solar when the sun is shining, and turbines when the wind is blowing. (I don't know about you but I'd like to have power on calm nights). Batteries you say. Well, unfortunately, batters are pretty terrible storage devices compared to fossil fuels. For example, let's compare the energy density of one (1) gallon of gasoline (which weighs about 6.3 lb.) to Lithium Ion batteries (same technology as tesla batteries). After some quick googling, I found that one (1) gallon of gasoline can produce approximately 33kwh of electricity (this means that it can provide 33,000 watts of energy for 1 hour). 33kwh of energy in a little 6.3 pound package. Lets compare that to Lithium Ion batteries. A Li-Ion (short for Lithium ion) battery that contained the same 33kwh of energy would weigh an astonishing 291 pounds.

Lets put this example in a easier to comprehend package. The tesla model s has a 85kwh battery in it. This battery weighs an incredible 1,200 pounds. However, this is only equivalent to about 2.58 gallons of gasoline. This means that, 2.58 gallons of gas (weighing in at a mere 16.26 pounds) stores the same amount of energy as the 1,200 pound tesla battery.

Now. Let's talk about taxing the super rich. First off. Lets make a distinction between super rich people and super rich corporations. The video mainly talked about rich corporations so I'll talk about them here. Let's take a quick look at what is happening to New York and California (which are both heavily taxing big corporations). THE BIG CORPORATIONS ARE LEAVING!!!! Let me ask you a question. If you lived in a town where you, only, were taxed 90% of your income, but the next town over only charged you 30%, would you stay or leave?
Let's talk about the after affects of companies leaving for a bit. First off, they take all the jobs with them. This means that, not only are you getting more people depending on unemployment (which steals taxe payer dollars from renewables) but instead of getting the "little" tax money from those companies, you're now getting zero.
So, by heavily taxing the super rich, you are not only, not getting more tax money. You're gonna be losing a lot of your current tax revenue.

8:00 Taxes paid by the richest corporations are not a good proxy for taxes paid by the rich. The rich do get most of their money from business income. But most business income is earned by pass-through entities like partnerships and LLCs, not by corporations, and most pass-through entity income accrues to the rich.https://review.chicagobooth.edu/economics/2017/article/never-mind-1-percent-lets-talk-about-001-percent https://www.brookings.edu/research/9-facts-about-pass-through-businesses/#fact4 So looking at taxes paid by the richest corporations only gives you part of the story of how the rich pay or don't pay taxes. The American tax system is all ready more progressive than that of most other rich countries. The U.S. levies an average effective corporate tax rate of 24%. The average rate is 20% (calcualted in excell from OECD data). So yes, we do tax our corporations. Just not the ones that you mentioned. We do tax the rich, just not by taxing the richest corporations, because taxes paid by the richest corporations are an ingredient in taxing corporations, and the rich, but not the only ingredient in either of those things. Progressive taxation tends to hurt economic growth generally. https://www.economist.com/united-states/2017/11/23/american-taxes-are-unusually-progressive-government-spending-is-not https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=CTS_ETR (average calculated in excel). https://www.oecd.org/mena/competitiveness/41997578.pdf. That period of strong growth you mentioned was after the rest of the world was destroyed in the 2nd world war. So they had to buy all new stuff from America. So your case for taxing the rich is not as strong as it sounds.
So then how do we pay for it? simple, "We" don't. The people who are causing the problem pay for it. 100 companies are responsible 71% of C02 emissions. https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/jul/10/100-fossil-fuel-companies-investors-responsible-71-global-emissions-cdp-study-climate-change
So we make them pay for it through carbon taxes.
tl;dr. The solution isn't so much to tax the rich, as it is to tax the people putting the C02 into the air in the first place. We all ready tax the rich, and it appears to not be conducive to economic growth.

A bit simplistic, but reasonable.

Taxing the rich? No. Taxing EVERYONE fairly. Yes. The campaign is not “we need to dump the costs on the rich”, but instead “we need those that benefit most from the economy to start paying their fare share.”

Corporations may not be the best place to get the money, Amazon pays little taxes because they are actually able to offset any income. Change the rules, they change the way they play. Shareholders, executives, etc. is where the money is. Besides, corporate taxes (like tariffs) are just passed down the line to the consumer.

Finally, yes, the goal should be near 100% non-fossil fuel. 2050 would be a nice target. But all of the alternatives currently have significant downsides too. Solar cell manufacturing produces toxic waste, often requires rare Earths, and have a limited lifespan after which they typically end up in landfills where they leech more toxic materials, plus peak efficiency has been stuck at 25% for more than 15 years. Wind has it’s own problems, including the 10 year lifespan of the current blades, after which they end up... in landfills. Nuclear, well if nothing else, politics. Batteries, yep, including that there is very little recycling.

One area you leave out though, is efficiency. Of all the ways of moving to a non-fossil fuel future, there is one with little downside. That is efficiency, or the overall reduction of energy usage. Besides a 1:1 cutback in GHG production from just not creating the energy in the first place, it also makes it easier to transition. Oh, and this ALSO means more jobs.

My question to you is why tax only the rich? We could get way more money from taxing everyone and not only a small group of people, especially when these people are the most important to our country. The rich already pay high income taxes on their personal income. Their wealth is mostly in stocks, if they want to get some of that wealth they need to sell the stocks and pay a 20% capital gains tax.
Let's take Jeff Bezos for example:
His net worth is 202 billion but his annual salary is only 81,840(which he pays income and self employment tax on like everyone else). his wealth is in stocks, if he wants to spend it, he needs to sell some of the stocks. Whenever he sells these stocks he does it mainly for donations and for funding his space company, he also pays a 20% capital gains tax for the government when doing this. If we taxed his wealth and capital gains more, he wouldn't have the money to donate and invest in his space company. A 70% income tax above
10,000,000 won't do anything to him because his income is only 81,840 per year. It is true that amazon paid 0 corporate income taxes but corporate income taxes don't only hurt the owner of the company, it hurts the whole company. Even scandinavians know that which is why corporate taxes there are about the same as in the US(without all the tax loopholes though). Corporate taxes are taxes on companies, not on company owners.
It is true that taxes were high in the 1950's to 1960's but the rich weren't the ones paying those taxes. The top 1% in that time paid an average tax of only 42% which is not much higher than what they pay now. The main reason for that was extremely generous tax deductions. Another reason is that a lot of people just stopped paying taxes, illegally. https://taxfoundation.org/taxes-on-the-rich-1950s-not-high/
The economy is not a zero sum game. Rich people are the ones who produce our wealth and make it that way. If we tax them, we will grow our economy less.
I believe that there should be low corporate taxes, low taxes for investors(the lower tax on investors the more we can tax them, do the math), low taxes on rental income and less tax deductions and loopholes.
The income tax should be 40% above $50000. People who have a business and get income from another source and not their own business will pay less tax on that income( that will encourage people to start businesses). I also believe in ending social security and forcing business owners to save money for their worker's retirement (the money the businesses save for their employees will not be taxed). My plan would not only bring us enough money for college school and healthcare vouchers but will also speed economic growth. Countries make most of their money from income taxes which is why raising income taxes and making them more flat will bring in more money.

I believe in taxing the money that the rich spend on themselves (normal income) but I don't believe in taxing the companies or real estate that the rich own because they need that money to invest it back.

To summarize, they will depend on their peer interconnectivity, and so can you really say that you're carbon neutral when you depend on your polish neighbourgh that does electricity with coal (or you're nuclear free when you depend on France with it's nuclear power plants )?
About electric cars, you've not talked about lithium availability, for example when BoA says 40% in 2030, it doesn't take in account the enormous mass of lithium that it would require to achieve this. Nuclear is NOT the solution and here are just a couple of reasons why. A nuclear reactor in its most basic form is no different than a coal boiler or natural gas plant. All the reactor is doing is creating heat so the heat can boil water to create steam and the steam can turn a turbine which can create electricity. For example, a reactor and its generating plant; a coal plant or natural gas plant are all about the same when it comes to operational efficiency. They all waste about 65% of all of the BTU's of heat energy they create either from the lost of that heat in the generation process or in operational thermodynamic inefficiencies. So only about 35% of the heat created actually does the real work of creating electricity. It is not the inefficiency of the reactor or boilers but rather all of the other equipment that is needed to create electricity like the water pumps, electric motors, heat exchangers and turbine generators. So the using nuclear fuel or ANY other form of fossil fuel is not the complete solution we need.

Now we come to what is called Waste Heat. You know the heat lost in the process of generating electricity. The heat we loose in the piping, the reactor or boiler or turbine or even the water we use to cool the power plant. Sixty-Five (65%) of that heat goes to waste. So where does that excess or waste heat go? Well it goes directly into our environment which in some cases is our air or stream or river or if the power plant is located near the ocean it is dumped into the ocean. And during this whole generation process we are using billions upon billions of gallons of fresh water to cool the power plant and it doesn't make any difference what type it is. So certainly waste heat rejection and water use are all going to have to change IF we ever become serious about cleaning up the air we breathe and the water we drink.

But solar, wind and water systems do not have these same waste heat or thermodynamic principles to overcome. Lets take solar for example. When the sun comes up in the morning the solar panels start creating electrical power and when the sun goes down they shut themselves off. No power plant operators are even needed. Utility workers at a central dispatching office turn the system off and on as needed by the electrical grid. Now lets consider the difference between that solar plant and a nuclear plant. There are usually about 200-400 people who work 24/7/365 at a nuclear power plant and some of those workers need to be licensed by the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission [USNRC] which is a very expensive process. So lets consider the difference between 200-400 operators, maintenance workers, engineers, safety officers and licensed personnel vs a workforce of 1-3 unlicensed workers at a solar power plant. Try multiplying the number of workers by about $30-$60/hour and then compare the difference. And of course you might need to replace a solar panel from time to time but as a utility executive, which would you prefer?

Now of course the sun doesn't shine at night but solar can be used to charge batteries during the day or to pump water up a hill for later generation or it can create hydrogen which can be burned at night to create power. About the same can be said for wind turbines. Now I am not saying that ALL nuclear is unnecessary since certainly some nuclear will be needed under certain conditions. But certainly 75% of our energy needs could be supplied by solar, wind and water systems. When I retired from the nuclear power industry in way back in 1995 which is now some 25 years ago, we were already considering Small Modular Reactors [SMR], Molten Salt Reactors [MSR], High Temperature Gas Cooled [HTGR] reactors. So here we are some 25 years later with only one approved design and we haven't even completed the construction of the first prototype power plant yet. Now if you happen to be the type of individual who is concerned about global warming, do you really want to wait for another 10 or 15 years to do something about the warming of our planet? I certainly don't. I want a massive build out of solar, wind and water systems along with more geothermal, biomass and other renewable systems. I want more Electric Vehicles [EV] now and not 10 years from now. I want a national electrical grid that spans more than just a few states. And certainly we need to stop wasting 65% of all of the heat energy we create if we are going to survive with 8-10 billion people on this planet. As a society we can not continue to waste energy the way we have been going forward. Please study the linked chart to see what we should be working on. https://flowcharts.llnl.gov/

Solar and Wind are cheaper on a per unit basis. However they have dispatchability issues and are therefore in a selling to grid scenario, the energy is worth much less than dispatchable energy (gas turbines, solar thermal, pumped hydro, etc.)

One way to work around increasing renewable load is to use gas turbines as dispatchable energy to full in the gaps in the interim and over time you would transfer to dispatchable renewables / energy storage systems *which currently cost approximately 3x as much on a per energy unit basis. Note this won't mean your power bill will go up 3 fold.

@AsapSCIENCE - The facts you've given are corrent, but incomplete, leading some folks to incorrect conclusions. There are MANY ways to store renewable energy and several more ways to procure it in the first place. They have not become mainstream YET, but they have been in development for years and are about to come online. For instance, Makani Kites can tap winds far above where birds and bats fly, use much less material per unit of power produced, can almost always find wind at some altitude, and do not need ANY wind in order to launch. New perovskite photovoltaic cells are being made with no toxic or rare elements in them, designed from the start for easy recycling, and showing good efficiency already. Then for storage, there is compressed air in caves and tanks, Liquid Air for both short term storage and long term, hydrogen from electrolysis of water, methane and methanol synthesis from CO2/CO+hydrogen (from electrolysis), and the very simplest energy storage is thermal.
Resistance heat can get hotter than any common fuel, mere sand and rocks can store it almost anywhere in huge quantities, thermal-insulated storage has excellent economies of scale, and the heat can be added/extracted by any number of working fluids, to suit the attached equipment. Concentrated sunlight also works well with thermal storage, as do molten salts for the storage medium. Then to use the stored heat...
Why don't fossil fuel power plants install high temperature thermal storage, integrate it into their Heat Engine cycles, draw from it for peaking and when the renewables have a lull, then replenish the storage when renewables are peaking, AND when the baseload plants have excess power themselves? Nuclear plants in particular would benefit hugely from using hotter steam, which would boost the conversion efficiency of their reactor heat, while also letting them follow the load demand AND keep the reactor running at peak all the time. Most thermal power systems use reheat too, so they don't even have to store heat at their peak temperature.
New options and beneficial combinations of technologies are so abundant, I can't even count them all. The future is bright, it just takes a while to arrive!

Sorry folks, the biggest lie about renewables is that nuclear isn't renewable, the next is that solar resources can solve the fossil carbon problem, and the third is that nonsense to the effect that there is any portion of the solar input that can reasonably be diverted to industrial use.

Take hydro power, which is by far the most reliable solar origin resource. At a cost of 2250 kJ of solar energy per kg of water (that's per litre) or indeed 2250 MJ per cubic metre, sea water is evaporated and the winds blow it over the land, where it rains or better yet becomes snow -- releasing most of that energy to the upper atmosphere or outer space, which is a Good Thing.
Now, the gravitational energy of a tonne of water (1000 kg) at a height of 102 metres (about twice the height of Niagara Falls) is 1000 x 9.8 x 102 is one megajoule, 1 MJ, so the solar efficiency of hydropower for a 102 metre "head"is one in 2250. But the collection area for that power is hundreds or even thousands of miles of ocean. It is even stored energy, to the extent that it's the winter snows.

Wind power was king of the seas in 1776 and even in the days of Napoleon and Admiral Nelson. It was swept away by coal and oil. Yet sail drives a ship far more effectively than wind responds to megawatts per minute rise in demand on the grid.
There are two reactions by which the supply of fissile nuclear resources are indeed renewable. Neutron capture by thorium 232 produces protactinium 233 which decays to fissile uranium 233, and uranium 238, through neptunium 239, to plutonium 239. In 2019, 10% of Virginia's electric power came from such plutonium, because even a PWR gets 1/3 of its power from plutonium generated in the reactor, and EIA figures for MWh of energy in 2019 show that 30% of Virginia's was nuclear, and other trustworthy figures show that the "capacity Factor" was over 95%. That of course is because it can serve a steady demand, and the fuel cost is the least of its expenses.
But it is also by far the lowest emissions alternative, even although deliberate breeding from Th-232 or U-238 might be a hundred times better.

The fact is that three kilograms of thorium or uranium contains as much available energy as the biggest pumped storage unit in the world, one gigawatt.day's worth. Capriciously weather dependent renewables demand three or four times their average MW production power, of storage. Or else for every 100 MW of their actual output that we're using, responsible grid managers pay for nearly that much "spinning reserve", which is usually a gas turbine that could be producing that power, but isn't. It's still burning gas to keep it spinning.

The video glossed over one of the most important parts: renewable energy sources are not good options for a "base load" of power supply because their supply is variable. The only way renewables can replace existing base load sources is to create power storage options for holding the power generated at a scale that simply does not exist today.

That's the obstacle that needs to be cleared: storage of power that's generated in excess of current requirements.

For obvious reasons, solar only works when the sun is up. And no smart grid, however much it's hyped, is going to be able to address the fact that the entire United States is in darkness at the same time - which means solar can NOT be a reliable supply of power without some way to store that power at night. Sure, it's possible - but without some really exceptional advancements in electrical storage and massive reductions in cost per megawatt hour for storage you're not really capturing the true cost as compared to fossil fuels.

For that matter, you've also ignored the potential that radioactives play in our energy future. The most modern version of a nuclear power plant, if built today, would probably be a molten salt reactor with thorium fuel - which is not subject to the kinds of accidents that older nuclear power technology were subject to. And they are suitable for providing a base load and aren't impacted by darkness or calm winds...

The problem with energy sources and the stability of the grid is not only a problem of quantity , but also a problem of quality. Different energy sources are used in different time periods in a day to respond to the load demands, the peak and base demands. PV and wind energy are a clean energy source , but at the same time many times unreliable. Ofcourse there are patterns of how the weather acts, but the problem is that many times there are things that we are not able to forsee, like the demand side. So to amend this problem we have power sources like Hydro or natural gas stations that can react quickly to changes of demand. Also the sudden changes in load , without the inertia that rotating machines provide, a change in demand can easily result in an offsetting of the network's frequency (50hz or 60hz ). So to sums things up, renewables yes, green energy yes ( not nuclear, it is not green) ,hydro YES(i wonder why no one mentions it), but it need better planning.

The biggest lie is this video.

For example renewable is not cheaper than fossil. That is the biggest lie of all. "Fossil fuel is only viable because it is subsidized by the government". This is, essentially, projection. What's being called "subsidized" is actually tax breaks and the like. You see, when you have a company wanting to set up shop, they can choose between country A, B, or C. Therefore, A, B, and C all must compete with each other. A tax break is an incentive offered to the company. AOC learned this lesson the hard way in NY with Amazon. Amazon was willing to set up shop in NY provided they got a tax break. Now, a tax break doesn't mean they don't pay taxes, it means they just pay less tax. AOC refused and now NY gets full taxation on exactly $0. Way to go AOC <slow clap>.

This is different than an actual subsidy that the renewable industry gets in grants and other sources. Okay I've done 10 minutes and going by the rate of new points they make I think I've seen enough to properly respond to this.
Some of the things they don't tell you in this are thus: how companies react to being taxed very highly, the reliability and waste of renewables (as yes they do have waste), and a few other things that should be thought about though I'll admit I've not much information on.
First off: companies very much do not like being taxed and the way they avoid taxes is by hiring very expensive lawyers and accountants to study the tax code and tell them exactly how to manage it. This is also incentivized by having a very high tax rate and the reason the 90% tax rate was done away with is because the companies weren't paying taxes ANYWAY. A few other tricks are having companies located out of the US, creating a company that owns the main company and making its headquarters in a nation with more favorable taxes. Point is there is a variety of ways of getting out of taxes and having higher taxes on these companies simply disincentivizes them from actually paying taxes in their county. That's one.
Two: the price and reliability of renewables are very... poor at best logistically. Yes photovoltaic cells have dropped in price dramatically, however that doesn't take into account how often they need to be replaced, how much time they're actually producing energy. These things are incredibly location dependent, have an effect on the local population, and are almost never producing the exact energy a population needs at any one time with no real way to store the excess as the batteries we currently have to hold them are incredibly expensive and inefficient for that purpose. This means that there is tons of wasted energy throughout the day and tons of energy getting powered by those dang coal plants anyway and thus negating their benefit much like the point of the electric cars. They also end up as extremely hard to clean up technological waste in a dump somewhere with a new shipment from a farm on the average of every five years. Honestly the only reliable one here ends up being hydro which has the ultimate problem of location dependency, issues with transmission (the least of our worries), and also a damage to ecosystems (which wind and solar do too) as these are very extensive ways of energy that require a lot of room and land. The energy source with precisely 0 of these issues is nuclear. And comparatively the safest power source because somehow solar and wind farms are killing people. You can't make this stuff up.
Third and finally: how vehicles end up affecting this. So electric cars are a neat idea however they do end up with some significant drawbacks in that they require much longer to charge than pumping gas, draw upon the energy grid directly, and run on those batteries that need to be put in throughout the car. I think the best two solutions to this are bio-fuels and hydrogen cell cars. Bio-fuels are completely renewable in the fact that they are grown and harvested from crops and as a result can be ready made, basically never run out, and will continue to be made as long as you can produce it. The drawback to this is that it is still technically burning carbon, however you're also planting more plants that thus take up more carbon from the atmosphere and thus depending on the ratio about even out but can lean in one direction or another. The other one is fuel cell cars which I personally appreciate as they are technically batteries, however they aren't limited by the size of the battery and instead use oxidized hydrogen to create the electricity to run the engine. So as long as you have hydrogen you can effectively create electricity. It's also made by the electrolosis of water meaning that although it does come from the grid it's only a limited amount of electricity going into water to make hydrogen and oxygen which means more oxygen released and then more water released from the ambient oxygen when its combined with the hydrogen in the car evening out the whole process.
I think the people who are educated on these topics know very well about why some of the things in this video do and don't work and why it's not just the lobbying of these companies especially since some of them are actually working on biofuels! I think it's extremely uneducated and naive to promote these things as some sort of miracle solution to everything and I suggest you check out the channel "Real Engineering" to see them discuss some of these issues which asap science has so callously glossed over in a bid for brownie points by supporting the renewables which don't work as well as they should.

First, a quick look at Amazon’s financial statements shows it does pay taxes. In 2017, Amazon paid close to $1 billion in income tax. In 2018, the amount jumped to $1.18 billion, accounting for local, state, and international taxes.

Amazon pays plenty in terms of payroll taxes and also state and local taxes. Nor should you forget the taxes paid by Amazon’s employees on their wages. Not only is that direct revenue to various levels of government, but the incidence of those taxes falls somewhat on Amazon, which now must pay higher wages to offset the tax burden faced by their employees," Cowen adds.

It is true that in the last two years, Amazon did not pay federal taxes. (It's odd to think I paid more federal tax last year than Amazon did.) But before yelling partiality, it is worth understanding why. A more thorough examination of the underlying economics demonstrates that only looking at Amazon's profits versus corporate taxes is too simplistic of a model.

Instead, a good place to start is understanding economic incentives. Incentives, in laymen's terms, sound like free money. Incentives, to an economist, operate as a lever to generate a better result which offset the cost. Taxes are one such lever. But taxes are too often interpreted only by their first-order effect of generating revenue, rather than the second-order effect of stimulating economic activity.

If you look at the Internal Revenue Code, as one CPA cites, less than 1% of it is dedicated to revenue generation. The majority, in fact, is on tax deductions. “There are only about 30 pages in the Code that actually raise revenue...[T]here are about 6,000 pages that tell you how to reduce taxes through tax deductions, tax credits and other incentives.”

Tax deductions can be incorrectly categorized as “crony capitalism.” But tax deductions, tax credits, and other incentives act as an important driver for organizations to then stimulate economic activity, job creation, and innovation.

Amazon's Tax Breaks And The Underlying Incentives

There are three main drivers of Amazon's tax breaks:

Investment in Research & Development. Amazon invests heavily in research and development and therefore benefits from the tax credit. In 2017, as Recode stated, Amazon topped the list of U.S. companies in R&D spend, at $22.6 billion. The next closest was Alphabet at $16.6 billion. Many of Amazon's innovations have been birthed from this investment.
Investment in Property, Plant, and Equipment. Amazon’s investment in property, plant, and equipment also makes it eligible for tax credits. Cities can benefit from Amazon's investment in real estate and job creation (benefits New York City could have enjoyed). Amazon's PPE expenditure has steadily increased over the last five years, netting to approximately $60 billion as of the end of last year.
Employee Stock Compensation. A move away from cash compensation to stock-based compensation for employees is the third driver of its tax breaks. Tax deductions increase as the stock increases. While this can certainly create adverse incentives, it is important to assess the benefits it creates relative to the cost. While such a tax policy can introduce misaligned management incentives, it also generates incentives for management to drive the best possible return for investors.

Amazon largely pays no corporate tax precisely because it reinvests those profits into its operations. Under a scenario where Amazon had no corporate tax breaks, it would disincentive the company from reinvesting and thus creating greater opportunity for the businesses and cities in which it operates.

Raising a pitchfork to fight Amazon's corporate tax breaks is fine if the argument is rooted in strong economic reasoning. The risk is that too often the data is pulled out of context, and inaccurate storylines circling that data gain momentum and undeservedly accelerate.

The building impetus to tear down existing economic structures without a strong grounding in why the structures even exist could land us in a worse position. The question to address is not why Amazon pays no taxes, but under what tax structure could we be better off?

Something I'm surprised you didn't go much into was energy storage. Batteries have issues -- Lead acid has limited capacity and toxic materials, Lithium based batteries can be expensive and have limited cycles, but one great way to store energy is with mechanical batteries. There are places that do this already in a number of forms -- pumping water to a higher elevation during the day when solar is generating or when there's a surplus from wind, and allowing it to flow back down to a lower elevation when power production is low and running hydroelectric generators to make up for it; spinning up a high-efficiency flywheel during surplus and using that rotational energy to create electricity again later; mechanical storage can offer long-lived, often simple and more easily maintained, as well as larger scale for lower cost, than traditional battery storage, especially on a nation-wide scale.

Also, nuclear didn't get a lot of love! And it can be much more consistent than solar or wind, and match energy needs very well if the reactor is run properly. France is like 80% nuclear at this point, and it's doing pretty well for them. As long as we have well-built reactors, we don't really have to worry about accidents, and there are newer reactor technologies that can take advantage of the waste material from standard fission reactors to produce more power, instead of just filling caves with radioactive waste like we've been doing.

There is a huge problem here. People tend to automatically think of renewables as good. Their operation doesn't directly lead to air pollution or carbon emmisions and they are "natural". For a start this is an appeal to nature fallacy(look it up). The other thing is you can't just look at a renewable energy technology in a vacuum. They keep claiming that renewables now produce energy cheaper than fossil fuels. While directly that is true, it isn't true when you look at the grid those renewables exist in. Because wind are solar are intermittent, largely uncontrollable sources you must have technologies in your grid that can compensate for sudden changes in output and the complete loss of energy production from those sources. So for every solar or wind farm that gets built, guess what? A natural gas plant gets built too to deal with this problem. You might be tempted to say "oh, well that natural gas plant only has to work when the renewables aren't so it's still a net positive". But again, things aren't so simple. Not only did you have to build 2 sources of power to do the job that one could do on it's own, driving up cost. It also increases emmisions because the "simple cycle" natural gas plants that can react quickly enough to sudden changes in the output of renewables don't have very high efficiency and their emmisions spike every time they have to quickly ramp up power. I'd argue that if the output of the renewables vary too much it would be better for the environment to just use a more efficient "combined cycle" natural gas plant and just forgo the renewables entirely. Look at Germany and other countries that are determined to add lots of renewables. Their electricity prices are double that of their neighbors and their emmisions are still significantly higher. Compare nuclear powered France to renewables-heavy Germany.

If you wanted to use batteries to get around the intermittent nature of wind and solar you run into a different problem. Not only are storage systems expensive but even if they were cheap they don't produce electricity, only store it at the cost of a drop in efficiency. The problem then is the amount of energy used to create, install, and maintain the renewable source plus it's storage systems leaves you with a tiny amount of energy surplus left over to do anything with. Researchers estimated that a modern society needs an energy source that produces 15x more energy than it consumes. Most fossil fuels get a score of about 30, nuclear 75-100, wind 15-20, solar 6-15, but if you take wind and solar and add even the best energy storage and that number drops well into single digits thereby making them useless to a modern nation.

The next problem with wind and solar is their massive use of resources. It's estimated the amount of material waste(including highly toxic waste) from solar per unit of electricity produced over it's life is 300x higher than than of nuclear power. Wind isn't much better. And most of these materials either aren't recyclable or it is prohibitively expensive.

Lastly is land use and interaction with the habitats or native species. Wind and solar take up huge land areas due to their low energy densities relative to fossil fuels or nuclear. Go ask the German people how they feel about the expansion of wind farms in their country. Wind power and solar thermal plants kill an enormous amount of birds and bats. And we aren't just taking about small common birds but large and rare bird species that have populations that can't adapt quickly to these changes in environment.

Renewables have their place but that place isn't in large quantities on a national or international grid. They make electricity more expensive, don't significantly drive down carbon emmisions, use too much land/resources, and in large numbers THEY SIMPLY WON'T WORK.

What we need to do is work to make nuclear power cheaper and rid the general public of the numerous lies and misinformation they have been fed by malthusian so-called "environment groups"

I see some problems with this presentation. First of all, solar and wind are impractical when blown into proportion. At 2:27, it is mentioned that 1/100 of the sun’s energy that reaches Earth can power the global economy 6 times over. So, the global economy requires 1/600th of the energy we can harvest from the sun. The surface area of the Earth is 197 million square miles, meaning we would have to build solar panels over an area of 326,000 square miles to meet the world’s energy demands. I understand that the density of solar energy changes with the curvature of the Earth, and building solar panels closer to the equator will be more effective, but this is still the equivalent of filling an area the size of Texas with solar panels. How about the wind alternative. Well, 20% of the wind on Earth powers the world’s yearly energy demands 8 times over. Meaning that we would need to harness 2.5% of all wind power in the world. If you have 40 cubic feet of air, you would need to harness 100% of the wind from 1 cubic foot. Now instead of 40 cubic feet, you are now required to harness that same 2.5% but from every point on the surface of the Earth. I’m all for optimistic thinking, but this project seems nearly impossible. It should also be mentioned that we have not found reliable methods for storing solar and wind energy. Recently, a 120 degree heat wave swept through Southern California, causing a spike in energy demands to keep houses cool, and the Los Angeles mayor released a statement to not use air conditioning because there was an energy shortage. This is because Southern California is heavily reliant on solar and wind energy, and to fix the problem, energy was needed from neighboring states.
Next, I’m surprised that the reasoning for leaving fossil fuels was not mentioned in great extent. Not surprisingly, climate change is the most cited reason for leaving fossil fuels. However, the US was the number one reducer in carbon emissions last year, https://www.intelligentliving.co/amp/usa-greatest-co2-reduction-2019/ The real problem with the increase in world carbon emissions is going to come from developing third world countries, particularly sub-Saharan Africa, which are experiencing their own form of an industrial revolution, and as mentioned in the video, requires substantial amounts of energy. Currently, fossil fuels are significantly more abundant and practical in these areas, and an attempt to reduce carbon emissions in these developing nations will not occur without the eminent halt on their advancement.
It’s also unfortunate that nuclear energy was never mentioned. In terms of efficiency, nothing even comes close to it. Power plants are up to 2 times more reliable than fossil fuels, and up to 3.5 times more reliable than wind and solar. https://www.energy.gov/ne/articles/nuclear-power-most-reliable-energy-source-and-its-not-even-close. Nuclear energy receives a bad reputation for events such as Chernobyl, but when properly maintained, it is actually safer than other forms of energy. In the 50+ years that nuclear energy has been used in the US, not a single person in the US has died from them, whether catastrophic or long term exposure.
Lastly, the top 1% of income earners pay roughly 40% of the federal budget as it is. That is more than the bottom 90% of income earners. Despite being incredibly immoral, raising their taxes even more to pay for 100% renewable energy would only solve the carbon emissions in the US, and not address other countries which will continue to operate under more practical means to obtain energy. You will single-handedly obliterate a generation of investors who provide money for the exact renewable energy research that you praise, hollow out the US economy, destroy the free market, and cause an economic recession that our grandkids will still feel. But at least we’ll have windmills.

All for wind and solar, although the numbers shown are technically inflated. I work for a power company and we advertise over 20% renewable energy which we do produce roughly 20% of our total power from renewables. The caveat is that we do not actually account for the 20% on our base load.
The reasoning for this is we have virtually no grid level storage so as the power levels fluctuate with wind and solar due to clouds/wind variance, we can dip under our base load requirements. IE: if we need 1000 megawatts and we get 800 from nuclear 100 from coal, we can’t trust the last 100 megawatts of wind will constantly sustain the load forcing us to create more power using fossil fuels. So we truly account for about 10% of total renewable power as of now (at my company, idk about other power entities). Grid level storage can completely change that game and we should invest in that infrastructure in my opinion.

Nuclear is a good stop-gap, as we move from fossil fuel to sustainable generation, but that's only because we already have it, so we might as well use it. But it should never be regarded as a sustainable source of power generation - it is both very expensive (including the building and decomissioning/waste costs), and incredibly polluting (can you imagine proposing a power generation system that will produce a mass of highly lethal waste, which has to be kept safe for hundreds of thousands of years?!). We've got it, so we might as well use it, but, as soon as we can replace nuclear with sustainable generation, it should be shut down. And absolutely certainly, we should NOT be building any more nuclear generators!

Also, concentrating on wind and solar gives the fossil fuel companies an easy 'argument' against renewables - the wind doesn't always blow and the sun doesn't shine at night. For renewables to really work, we need to look, not just for ways of storing the power they generate, but also other methods of producing sustainable power. For instance tidal generators work 24/7, every day of the year, no matter what the wind or clouds are doing. Hydro is also a key source of power in many places, but is hardly mentioned in this video. Then there's thermal, biomass, etc. Sun+wind+batteries on their own will never win the argument.

We don't need, nor do we have time left, to ask why a complete transition to fossil free energy -- almost all of it renewable -- is needed. And while there's some range of results in science about whether we have three decades to get to zero fossil emissions or only ten years, it's clear our time to act is now.

Decades ago poor choices for temporary reasons were made on the international approach to global warming; those temporary reasons are long past, and it's time to re-evaluate those decisions: unilateral action as opposed to waiting for multilateralism; international trade action as opposed to social justice action; a Montreal Protocol approach instead of Kyoto..

We didn't know that only petro emissions explain 100% of the rise in GHGs, but since Rubino et al's 2013 work now we do. That means ending petro emissions is 100% of the job. Period.

We thought runaway to Hothouse was impossible or farfetched; as of Steffen and Lenton's independent researches by 2018 we realized it's entirely possible, meaning there's a one-way valve, a diode, a point of no return, and shockingly that point of no return is 50% likely at just 1.5 degrees C warming.. and we're over 1.1 degrees C, closer to 1.35 degrees C embedded warming.

We have, in short, only until 2030 to end fossil emissions, and that only if we start immediately. A doable rate is 10% of 2019 levels cut a year starting in 2021, so by the end of 2030 there is none.

Petro, Unilateral Montreal Protocol action to curtail fossil-emitting trade leverages the trade mechanism: every exchange has two parties, a buyer and a seller. The buyer refuses to buy, the seller is stopped; the seller refuses to sell, the buyer is stopped. In theory, in an unlimited Market those partners could go elsewhere, but in the real world we're in a petro glut, and sellers are selling now below the cost of production, so it makes economic sense for 10%-40% of them to exit the Market; they only remain because governments are forcing them to stay by failing to manage the transition to cheaper fossil-free.

Why has electricity cost in Germany increased as the share of renewables has increased?

Some facts (+/- source accuracy)
Year Electricity price (cent/kWh) Renewables share of Electricity mix (%)

2006 19.46 11.6

2019 30.22 40.6

For reference, in Texas electricity cost to consumers is ~10 cents/kWh.

A close analysis of Germany's data shows that Renewables are still much more expensive than fossil energy (you could in fact sell oil at 150$+ per barrel and still outcompete renewables). Then why is oil so cheap (~40 $/barrel at this time)? Because of overproduction from oil companies and oil-producing countries.

However, I concede that the trend is that renewable costs are going down quite rapidly. Will it continue? nobody knows. I think that renewables cost reduction will slow down due to running out of space and other limitations.

This video is pretty dishonest. Renewable energy sources are great and have tons of advantages! BUT there is also many disadvantages! If we are to have an honest discussion about renewable energy we need to highlight both the pros and cons and explain why it would be impossible to only use solar and wind to power everything.

One of the biggest issues with wind and solar is that it's not always sunny and it's not always windy. Electricity on this scale is extremely difficult to store! Wind and solar work great for a supplementary power source but cannot be relied about entirely, they must be supplemented but another constant power source capable of ramping up and down as the demand requires. Peak electricity demand is in the early morning and late afternoon whereas solar produces the least amount of electricity in the early morning and late afternoon.

Hydro power, Nuclear and natural gas being the best options to compliment wind and solar but even if the steady power source is coal implementing solar and wind are great options to reduce emissions.

PS I mentioned that electricity on this scale was extremely difficult to store but I have seen it done before! In the pacific northwest the majority of our power comes from Hydroelectric dams and during the day there is tons of demand but at night there is hardly and demand but the hydroelectric dam can still run at fill capacity. So at night when there is little demand they pump water up to the top of a hill then during the day they let it down from the hill and run in through a turbine to feed the grid. The process is not very efficient but its utilizing what would be wasted energy.

Nice facts, but MOST of the story is missing. The fact that lithium-ion batteries are still not financially feasible to support grid operations for greater than 4-8 hours (and not incentivized to do so, literally anywhere) causing the increased penetration of solar to imbalance the grid such that natural gas plants are more and more dominant because of their ability to quickly turn on and off with large power outputs (we have moved past oil into an age of natural gas, not renewables). The fact that if we could use energy storage as a reliability/resiliency measure, we would do so many incredible things by replacing diesel gen-sets and distribute the grid at the same time. The fact that there is, and this is big, NO infrastructure or policy basis for a smart grid, making it more of a pipe dream than a real solution. There are huge institutions (ISO) running the transmission grid and you would need to create equivalent, but more highly funded and more technologically advanced institutions across the country in order to manage a smart grid. That is a down the road solution, do not treat it like it can happen right now. A more realistic policy change is pushing for reliability (meeting grid power) and resiliency (working in case of emergency) credits to be given to energy storage for longer durations. THAT is what we should be pushing for. In addition, pushing for retirement replacement projects is HUGE. These replacement projects are one of the only ways that we can actually credit the cost of a carbon tax in a financial prediction of what the best solution is (solar/liion must compete with natural gas plants, and it will lose if you can’t credit carbon tax). Look up how California replaced SONGS as an example. This story also leaves out ANY mention of international balance of power when it comes to oil price, which is a huge lever when it comes to competing with communist governments that control their countries oil and benefit directly from the oil profits. Our continued competition in that arena is one of the only real things (other than nuclear) allowing us to negotiate with our enemies. I have so much more to say in terms of what technology can solve these problems and what financial policies allow us to do it while competing on an international stage, but first, I must demand that YouTube channels like this research it themselves. Thank you! (Also no-one ever mentions the power to gas cycle as a path to zero emissions, even though it takes advantage of existing infrastructure without forfeiting nearly as much international economic power. please mention the power to gas cycle)

Neither China or Germany provides good return on investment in regards to renewable energy, they both needs state subsidizes for solar and wind, whereas Britain and America don't. Britain and America still lead the pack on renewable energy, they just don't need to spend or invest anywhere as much to get the same amount of energy due to ideal geography for wind(UK, Us mid west and east coast) and solar generation(US). Britain left the EU and took away HALF of Europe's total wind and tidal energy potential, Britain is also going to go carbon neutral much sooner than the rest of the EU without the same price tag. Doesn't matter of Germany already invested more than a € trillions in renewable because the early wind turbines and solar panels had lower capacity and were more expensive, off shore wind was doubly so. Britain on the other hand has reliable(working at 33% Vs 20% capacity year round) enough and fast wind right on it's door step close to ground elevation and also close it's population centres thus not needing a large over capacity, taller wind turbines or the laying down of as many mileage of thick copper cables to transport the electricity to the population centres. Distance increases the need for thicker cables to due the electrical resistance and requires more voltage for the same power output, the high the voltage and resistance the more maintenance required for the cables, which china ain't particularly good at maintenance. Large over capacity also increase the potential electrical fluxes, which can blow the substations if there are sudden surges, German manufacturing plants are have obtain their own power generators to provide extra redundancies against black outs. The large wind farms in China over in inner Mongolia, Tibet and Xinjiang province are a vanity project for propaganda purposes, China overproduce copper, concrete, steel and when they can't dump it on the world market they need to use it up and it boost their GDP figures with infrastructure projects such as ghost cities, one belt one roads project. These winds farms are located in high altitudes, hundreds of miles inland, which makes transport very expensive especially considering the size of the wind turbines, in remote and sparsely populated areas hundreds of miles away from the coastal population centres that make up 80%+ of the Chinese population. In America, California has huge solar power generation with Tesla energy storage facilities to help fill the supply and demand peak, Texas has both solar and wind which can compete in price with oil which is also produced in large amounts. BP is active in the US and pursuing in solar energy generation, Shell is pursuing Wind energy generation both are British and will potentially end up being the world's largest wind and solar companies in the future, both produce alot of natural gas that can be fired up even out the energy flux and fullfil the energy demand no matter the weather. Although there aren't any US oil majors pursuing renewable energy they have Telsa, which make wind and solar more viable, whilst pushing for electrical vehicles and the charging facility infrastructure.

4:43 with an astristic. while there might be little more density to to squeezed out of the Li-Ion batteries most manufactures have actually shied away from increasing energy density beyond current levels. the reason being pretty simple, the cost just isn't worth the pay off. the concentration now is on getting batteries to as low a price point as possible. most are doing this by reducing the cost of expensive hard to source materials. the Ultima batteries from the LG, GM, Honda, and others partnership has particularly interested me.

In the automotive world there is also a shift way from "as much range as possible" and have also moved towards "guaranteeing the advertised range." It seems the actual range customers car comfortable with is around 200 miles and so long as they consistently get that range, they are find with it. there is a asterisk for moving up or down in price bracket (100 miles is the minimum expectation for "budget cars", and 500 is the new bench mark after at the $100k club)

So while batteries might get cheaper, the density probably won't increase too much more for the typical car.
