One of the easiest ways to move faster towards renewables is to use energy when renewable energy is most abundant. Heat your water, cook bulk meals, wash your clothes and dishes, and run your pool pump when the sun is shining or the wind is blowing. If you have a 3D printer, run it during the day, not at night. Charge your batteries (including for your electric vehicle) during the day. There are so many examples. Much of the transition can be habitualised even before we think about needing to install huge amounts of storage on the grid. We don't have to be perfect at it, we just need to be mindful about when we're using power, because that will largely determine where it comes from. Create demand for renewables. Be mindful that if you're using power at night when there's no wind that it's coming from fossil fuels, so try to minimise that use where convenient enough. Going further into the meal prep example, cook during the day when you don't have work to freeze for reheating during the week. It uses a lot more power to cook a fresh meal than to microwave something already made. It'll also probably make you eat healthier and save heaps of time during the week. There's some misnomers in this. A 60% increase in efficiency for wind turbines, isn't the wind turbines getting more efficient, but rather a decrease in the system losses. Due to physics, the peak efficiency of wind turbines is ~40%, similar to internal combustion if the heat is used to heat or cool spaces. The turbine fins are pretty much tapped on efficiency as well.

While solar panels are getting more efficient, we can only bank on current levels of efficiency (~23% not in labs), not expected future results, which may not come.

Nuclear is currently the black sheep and no one seems interested (in the west) to build 4th Gen power plants.

Finally it has to be stated that like most things in life, the transition will be a 2 steps forward and 1 step backwards. For example the molten salt solar towers that have now been shutdown in the USA not because of oil, but because they never reached advertised output and money out for repairs and investors > money in from sales.

the benefit of renewables like Solar and wind is that they can be decentralized and incorporated within suburban and city centers.  The problem is that the mindset hasn't yet shifted from the idea of a centralized grid to a decentralized power network.  Solar and wind "farms" are actually bad implementations of renewable energy as they exist in places that would otherwise be inhabited by nature when there's no need for that.  Ultimately the BEST thing states and local governments can do is update building codes so that the most expensive part of renewable power systems are standard for all new construction.  Turbines and panels are actually very cheap.  Battery arrays, power management panels and professional wiring is not.   By making it law that all buildings must be wired for renewable power,  you're basically cutting the cost of entry to under $5k.  Which doesn't have to be spent all at once.  Considering that new housing is in such high demand, the sooner this happens the faster people adopt renewables, and the more stable and resilient our infrastructure becomes.

Subsidies are the entirety of the reason why solar and wind are the least bit competitive. Let me use my country, Australia, as an example. with subsidies power prices in the State of South Australia can be anywhere from -ve a couple of $ per MWh to A$2500 per MWh dependent on wind etc (or just plain blackouts as were the case in 2016 when the wind turbines killed the grid, at least they hadn't blown up their coal fired power station at that point).

So why does this situation come about? Well firstly there is no real competition between the technologies. The government regulated different prices for the producers depending on source as well as providing subsidies... not only that it mandates that the first drawing of power has to come from renewable sources, but in times of a glut the power has to go somewhere and the voltage has to be managed. The system that regulates the voltage itself had to go through about a thousand fold increase in the amount of money needed to be spent just trying to keep the voltage within spec and this value continues to increase as more pathetic systems are 'tacked on' to a grid with little forethought. Also through this the fossil fuel providers still have to pick up the slack even though production gives no return with the sun shines and the winds blow so effective coal fired power stations that are unable to close down since they are needed to pick up the slack that these renewables will DEFINITELY bring later has to be picked up.

There are generally 4 types of coal fired power stations, subcritical with about 38% efficiency up to ultra super critical with 44% efficiency, but it does no end there with further efficiencies planned with designs reaching 47% in the works. Not really a 'dead end'. btw they have said that on batteries too and that is a place for much change over the last couple of years so I do not discount potential of either side. Just the outright lies of what seem to be quite ideologically left wing propaganda rather than anything really 'sciency' .

Tacking the word science and scientists does not add weight to anything said since there are plenty on both sides of this argument. An example of this is climate change the basis for this silly jaunt into wasting money for supposed climate change. Reports come out claiming 97% climate scientists support the global warming theory, the first such joke came out around 2006 when some 10k scientists received an email survey... from the long list of questions asked those that responded they then determined after getting the data which 3 questions they would use and then looked through the groups to work out which scientists fitted what they wanted to claim to be climate scientists. The end result were three fairly weird questions being answered by about 78 'scientists' of their picking. Now that might sound pretty horrendous but it was better than the next one by 'cook the books' that upon revision of using his own criteria found that 0.3% supported that in the peer reviewed papers not 97% as he claimed but we know what the media reported.

Then what about actual number of scientists? Do we include atmospheric physicists? what about geologists? what about computer modellers? Well the IPCC automatically added every scientist involved in the IPCC reports regardless if they supported the notion or not. From this they reached about 8000 'signatories' some of whom challenged to be removed from the list by the owners of the 'signatures' themselves. Counter to that there is the Oregon Petition which in effect claims there is no concensus and holds 30000+ signatures of scientists, several thousand of which are PHDs asking not to act on the bogus science of the climate change scam. Now you could go to snopes to see a refutation of this except they actually offer zero evidence for their claims, the fields the scientists were qualified for were clearly identified. If a person was shown up as fake or not qualified or had their name added falsely there were removed as soon as possible unlike a 11000 'scientist' petition last year demanding immediate action on climate change only to find such great minds as Mickey Mouse from the Mickey Mouse School of the Blind and Zoology professor Araminta Aardvark from the University of Neasden. Funny enough no snopes article on that, very quiet.

I know you're mainly targeting an american audience, so it may be a delicate subject to bring up, but I feel like this video is ignoring the elephant in the room.

The fact of the matter is that simply slapping low-carbon electricity generation and electric vehicles everywhere won't cut it. Because we, in developed countries, simply consume *way too much energy*. For reference, electricity generation only make up ~25% of global final energy consumption.

We only have a budget of 1170 Gt of CO2 left to emit before the 2°C threshold is passed, permafrost and methane hydrates start melting, and the climate enters a feedback loop making global warming unmanageable. At our current rate (which keeps increasing year on year), that budget will be exhausted in 26 years time. We need to save up as much of that budget as possible to built the means of production necessary to maintain a decent quality of life in a sustainable way. Right now, we're wasting most of that budget on buying brand new cars, electronics, shitty processed food, or oversized houses.

We need to collectively accept that we have to go on an energy diet until the issue is resolved. That means accepting lower buying power.

Germany is a pretty terrible example to mention. In 2020, despite having produced more than 46% of its electricity from renewable sources, Germany's carbon grid density was a whopping 490g/kWh . For comparison, that's worse than if they literally generated 100% of their electricity from gas turbines (440g/kWh). That's even worse than the US (453g/kWh).

Their plan to phase out of coal (not to mention crappy lignite, pretty much the worst fuel you can think of) by 2038 is utterly laughable and unambitious, considering we need to drastically reduce our collective carbon footprint by 2030 or we're all in for a really, really bad time. They put themselves in a shitty situation by closing down usable NPPs, and now they desperately need a baseload generation method.

If you want actually good examples of how to transition to a low-carbon grid, look at Sweden, France or even the UK, with their respectively 12g/kWh, 38g/kWh and 233g/kWh electricity grids.

California is a great example. Brown outs in the summer are tight.

“Once again, a big part of the problem is that California regulators have left the state dangerously exposed to buying large amounts of imported electricity on the spot market during peak periods on days when there is extreme energy demand—what Mr. Wolak likened to going to the airport on Thanksgiving and expecting to fly standby.”

Only this time, the crunchtime for the state’s grid operator isn’t the actual power demand peak in late afternoon—it is when the sun starts to fall in early evening, and the renewable energy the state is increasingly dependent on begins to wane.
On many days, California’s grid operator now has to find 10,000 to 15,000 megawatts of replacement power—sometimes 25% to 50% of what it needs to keep the lights on—during a three-hour period as solar, and to a lesser degree, wind power, falls off. California often relies on imported power from other states to help fill its void. But when a historic heat wave gripped the Western U.S. this month, the state struggled to find a way to replace up to 8,000 megawatts of disappearing renewable energy each evening. It came up short on some days by as much as half that amount and had to call for rolling blackouts on Aug. 14 and 15.”
- The Wall Street Journal, Aug 23 2020

Also: the notion of a 'second industrial revolution' in America is stretching history to fit the US narrative.

Pretty much all those innovations were simultaneously, or even originally in Europe. The car: German invention. Telephone: British. Tv: British. Radio: Italian in Britain. Oil: britain, France and Russia engaged in the Great game to control the Middle Eastern supply lines for this commodity and others. The history of major oil companies : shell (Dutch/UK) , BP (UK) standard oil (US :exxonmobil and conoco) Total (France) and chevron (US) shows that the US was far from the only ones in on the oil game.

While both solar and wind might look green from the outside they both have their own set of environmental problems.
Both are a unreliable sources of energy! You don't have wind nor sun light 24/7 anywhere in the world! That means that you need somehow store that energy to be used when the demand is high and if you cant keep up with the demand you have to rely on petrol sources. While making solar panels and wind generators is "cheap" Batteries still very expensive, have a short life span and have a lot of environment harming substances.

Wind is almost unpredictable. You might have energy for months and all the sudden the wind stop blowing for 3 weeks. How are you going to keep up with the demand? No battery can last that long. You will have to fire up the coal-fired/gas power station.
Also wind farms can not be placed anywhere. There aren't many places in the world that have a high frequency of strong wind. And wind generators are extremely loud and their blades can easily kill any bird that might impact it. The loudness make the region habitable for ground animals and the blades are a danger for birds. Even if there isn't any in danger species the farm also must avoid the path of migratory birds that usually uses those high current winds to help in their migration.

Solar only produces energy during the day. Guess when the demand for energy is the highest? At night! You will need a giant array of batteries to keep up with the demand during the night. And solar only produces high amounts of energy on the summer. During the winter the production is severely harmed and you will again have to rely on coal-fired/gas power station.
Also solar farms require a lot of land to be implemented. That means that you need to deforest a lot of terrain to generate a substantial amount of energy. Deforestation is one of the worst offenders to the health of environment. So not a option.

So is there no solution? There is! But trying so sell wind and solar as the solution to all problems isn't it! Solar and wind are a part of the solution not the solution! Is the combination of many alternative sources of energy as possible. And there are many like Tidal Power, Wave power (its similar to Tidal), Nuclear Power (He shortly talks about it on the video but its extremely hazardous waste makes it hard to manage), Thermal Power (for places that can use it), Hydroelectric Power (It has its own environment problems), Biomass and some more.
The only ultimate solution is Fusion Energy and we might not be that far from it. I.T.E.R is the first Fusion Reactor with a prediction of a 10:1 break even that means that it will output 10 times more power than it consumes. its full power test is scheduled to happen in 2035 if everything goes according to plan.

Arguing that we need to phase out oil and coal is 100% correct. However, I feel this video argues its point in a sensationalized and frankly dishonest way.

The "energy from the sun hitting the earth" statistic is technically accurate, but irrelevant. We don't have anywhere near the technology or infrastructure to harvest even a fraction of that energy. The video acts as if doing so is trivial and the only reason we haven't done it already is due to Big Oil Propaganda.

There is a lot of talk about countries setting goals and announcing their intentions for everything from renewable energy to electric cars. The video treats these goals and intentions as fait accompli, despite decades of nations failing to meet their carbon emission targets or straight-up ignoring them. It would make a lot more sense to look at already accomplished projects to get a real sense of the cost and scale, rather than look at what countries "intend" to do and what they expect it to cost. The China data in particular is extremely suspect, given that they have consistently and provably lied about their pollution levels for decades. As a side note, Germany recently had a significant increase in its carbon emissions due to a strong anti-nuclear movement forcing them to rely more heavily on coal. Political "intentions" are far too fragile to be relied upon.

The IMF subsidy study makes two major mistakes. First, it has an extremely broad definition of "subsidy" for the specific purpose of inflating the figure to something more impressive. Second, it includes natural gas subsidies, which are a good thing from a climate change perspective. Related note, 80% of fossil fuel subsidies in the USA are for natural gas. That's the sort of thing we should encourage, not disparage.

The "internet of things" talk specifically mentions that such a system will be expensive and complex. The video then answers the question of cost and complexity with... a public opinion poll? How is that even relevant? I think having a "smarter" power grid is an excellent idea, but I'm not comfortable with the misleading way the issue of cost has been sidestepped.

The "renewable energy jobs outnumber fossil fuel jobs 3 to 1" statistic is a straight-up lie. There are millions of jobs in the USA that depend on fossil fuels, and this is arguably the biggest obstacle to transitioning to renewable energy. The video talks about transitioning fossil fuel jobs into renewable energy jobs, but glosses over just how extreme that transition is. The political importance of this cannot be understated. Any politician who ignores this is going to have severe trouble making any kind of progress, assuming they can even get elected at all.

The discussion on taxation and wealth is both bizarrely off-topic and severely misleading. Yes, we could pass an anti-rich-guy tax. All that's going to do is get them to move their assets to overseas tax shelters, assuming they haven't done so already. The whole thing comes across as an attempt to convince the viewer that somebody else will foot the bill for renewable energy.

Besides that, my major complaint is that the video completely neglects Natural Gas and Nuclear Power. Renewable energy is already very popular. The problem is that two of our best oil and coal alternatives have been stigmatized. Natural Gas is constantly lumped in with other fossil fuels despite drastically lower carbon emissions, and Nuclear Power probably deserves its own video on just how far people's fears and perceptions are from the reality. This is particularly important because these two technologies are critical for transitioning jobs away from coal and oil. It's a lot easier transition an oil plant worker to a nuclear or natural gas plant than it is to train them to manufacture lithium batteries.

Doesn't hurt that most of that area is as flat as a pancake and vastly unpopulated. The facts are that most states don't have the perfect setup for the massive scale of wind farms that we have which is already larger than Road Island yet only produce a max of 20GW of the 27GW theoretical max it is rated for. We still have tons more untapped space but this isn't going to work for all states as you can see why. BTW we are adding more wind everyday and even with the massive roll-out so far we have not been able to produce 20% of our states power needs. To compound the issue the growth of our state is matching our current expansion of wind power so the number may never go over 20%, i do hope that part is incorrect. Moving on to Solar commercial panels. Currently Solar panels are around 20ish percent efficient as you know and only work for around 6 hours at that efficiency. Even if you covered every square inch of roof and ground in some states you would never generate more than 50 of the power needs in the 6 hour window of the solar generation. So between the 2 power generation techniques you can understand that we are at a major short fall and will still need power generation of another type which is good that you understand that. I have no problem running running natural gas powered generation as it's fairly clean and allows quick scaling to account for drop offs in generation of wind and solar. If you are familiar with Texas power generation you will see that my state agrees with me on that.

Now lets talk about where you are misleading. Wind power has always been more efficient than coal, oil, nuclear, etc. the problem being that we can't control the consistency. Solar is still less efficient than just about any other form of energy production and again only produces at most 6 hours of power at that efficiency. Then their is the cost of solar cells which has come down but no one uses cells that small to generate power for the grid. Larger cells are used and when i say cells it generally takes around 32 to 96 cells in each solar panel. Yes the cost has come down in even in the past 8 years but efficiency has only improved in the single digits. In fact there are panels still made that are roughly the equivalent of 1970's panels in efficiency. I'm not even going to touch your break down of solar energy and capturing 1/100th of the energy provided to the earth cause it's beyond far fetched to think at our current state that is even remotely possible. Solar should be a great source of energy in the future..it's just not there yet and i hope that changes. You can't break the world if you have no way to currently fix it and we can't Thanos' snap half the people away to stop the influence of humans on our planet. I.O.T. is great but it's just going to use more power that some states are still struggling to make. Even in places where the power usage is know year on year places are taking power plants off line and under powering areas. This only causes more issues cause then people start buying generators in the millions and if you think centralized power generation is inefficient then you don't even want to know how bad the efficiency is on gas or propane generators.

So how do we fix the power generation? Well i would argue the problem is more in consumption then in power generation and if we can get that in check we would reduce the power needs by 30 to 40 percent which would make renewables more effective. Looking at the biggest power users in our own homes and why they use so much power. So those things are generally home air conditioning, food refrigeration and cook top/ovens. Not alot you can do about cook tops and ovens since the devices are just about efficient as you can get already and you are not getting away from not eating. I'm sure we still have some more improvement to food refrigeration although i think home air conditioning is the biggest power hog. This i believe would make the biggest dent in our homes power usage. I think people should truly understand how their home power usage would change dramatically given some upgrades in this area. I truly believe we should be building to a much higher standard in this day and age then we are. Simple changes in home construction could reduce your homes power footprint by around half while only slightly increasing the cost of the home. The big thing i think will help with power usage is to decentralize energy production/storage. I think more people need to get skin in the game on generating and storing their own power, this is already happening and want to continue to see it. There are much better methods for power storage in the form of mechanical batteries that have very few moving parts and are not toxic, although i still think there is a necessity for batteries for a buffer.

9:17 When going with that option it's important to remember that carbon tax is only effective when there is an alternative available. For example, taxing gas to the point of it costing 1.6€/liter (8.5$/gallon) is not going to make people switch to an electric vehicle if they can't afford to buy it, and it's definetly not going to make them "drive less" if driving is their only option of getting where they need. It's just going to make them pissed off. Also, carbon tax should be split into "short" and "long" carbon cycles. That would make sure that for example power stations/boiler stations running on biofuels aren't affected as much, like they have been here in Sweden where some even planned on shutting down due to the high carbon tax.

Point is, make sure to have alternatives accessible to those who you want to tax in this way, and most importantly: don't use tax to force change faster than it can realistically happen. Rushing change would lead to solutions that don't hold up long-term, and could cost even more to fix afterwards.

You missed a key problem in renewable systems. Storage. How do we store the excess when we create it and have it dispersed when we need it? Renewables would have no problems if we fix that. There are 3 sources of energy, solar (oil and coal are stored solar), tidal, and nuclear (stored supernova).

Unless we run power lines between continents, solar is only available part of the day, so needs storage. We can keep solar farms going 24/7 by orbiting (at 40,000 miles) many, very large (hundreds of square miles total), very simple, mirrors. 24/7 illumination means we only need 1/4 the solar panels, no storage, using tech we have today.

Wind results from uneven solar heating of the planet. It is usable only because we receive far more solar energy than we use (today). It isn't reliable and also requires storage.

Like solar, tides are only useful part of the day. Phase shifting can extend this, but is a form of storage that requires a lot of area.

Nuclear is the only source that produces consistent power, isn't very good for rapid shifts in power need.

We need storage, or orbiting mirrors.....

The issue with solar is that at the same time of the day it is losing efficiency,  demand for power increases (google duck curve). A better option would be to have wind/solar supplement nuclear and natural gas (in US natural gas is basically free because it is a by-product of fracking). But I do agree that we should get rid of coal and continue to work on making solar/wind more efficient and to invest more into nuclear energy.

For a science channel you sure do a poor job in showing all the facts.

Germany is relying less and less on coal fired electricity plants in its own country but when the sun doesn’t shine and the wind doesn’t blow enough to cover the electrical needs of its people, it imports electricity from surrounding nations who DO use coal powered electricity plants.

You praise China but China has pretty much no environmental laws and is building a new coal powered electric plant every month or so. It is able to build quick and cheap solar panels because of the lack of environmental laws and the slave labour it has. Most of the rare earth metals that are needed for creating solar plants come from China and they basically dig a giant hole in the Earth, spray chemicals on the rocks to get out the metal they want and then dump the remainder into a nearby lake or stream. This inevitably ends up poisoning local people but because it is China, no one can do anything about it. When done, they leave the giant hole in the Earth and if you happen to live nearby you are out of luck because they will not try and fill it back in.

Then there is this fantasy that all our electrical needs can be met by current solar on wind energy. This would be true if solar panels were much more efficient but they are not. We would have to jam solar panels over every inch of this planet to get close to the power needed for our energy consumption and that consumption does not include the up and coming need for more electricity because of the growing electric car market. Also, the sun does not always shine, so blackouts would be inevitable.

As for wind power, don’t get me started on the thousands and thousands of birds and bats that are killed and injured by these things that can only run when the wind is strong enough (not just a breeze) and when the wind isn’t TOO strong. It also has to be the right temperature or the internal machinery will break so if you build it somewhere that actually has a cold winter, then you need electricity to be pumped into these machines to keep them warm.

Yes, we need to get off fossil fuels but wind and solar are not ready yet for us to abandon oil. We will get there one day but screaming “believe the SCIENCE”! Every time someone brings up a counter argument will not change these facts.

Great video and illustrations! I had some time researching topics related to this in industry but there are some HARD & HARSH truths we have to understand:

- China is #1 for Renewable tech but it opens at least 1 coal power station per week in order to fuel their factories (including those making solar panels, batteries, wind turbines, cars etc for itself and for the rest of the world) hence why their is a horrendous pollution problem there. Germany had a similar problem and ended up disastrously producing more CO2 than before and making the already available public energy supply more expensive - issues like these caused the US to leave the Paris Climate Agreement. Even the ‘Green New Deal’ proposed by AOC and Bernie in the US was rejected at congress because it was too unrealistic and costly.
Try make your owe life emissions free and you’ll notice how tremendously hard it is - now imagine politicians doing the same but for the whole country 🤯

- The top emitters of CO2 are the 1st world nations. They are the leaders in battling CO2 emissions because they have the money, time and privilege to. The rest of the world doesn’t because, for example, 3rd world countries haven’t developed themselves enough to adequately ‘care’ about their air/environment YET and it’s very unrealistic to hold these countries to the same emissions standards are the 1st world countries (any targets they propose would be superficial at best). The best China, EU and US could do is to continue to optimise and streamline their current energy supplies and while reducing their consumption (incl. food, water and waste). Even if China, the US and EU alone meet their emissions targets that will NOT guarantee a decrease in global temperatures - that’s how much a multivariable this climate change problem is.

Unfortunately, India, Africa and S America will gradually become more developed, populations will increase as well as their needs and consumption (eg transport, agriculture, infrastructure etc) which will drive emissions at rates similar to that of China, the EU and US today! 🙁

I agree with almost everything presented in this video. One thing to note: (purely) electric cars and transportation are definitely not the solution for the mobility sector. Lithium batteries and similar chemical technologies only make sense on a small scale. The environmental impact of producing batteries and the increasing inefficiency with increasing storage capacity/weight is a big problem. Transportation, especially for long distance and heavy weight vehicles, can not be powered by electric batteries. Fueling vehicles with hydrogen is a great solution for this. The technology is save and ready for a big scale launch into the market. But here we got the chicken and egg problem: no existing infrastructure means no incentive for industries and private sector to purchase hydrogen cars and trucks. This goes the other way around. Without public subsidies and funding we are losing valuable time in the fight against climate change.

Rule n ° 1: One does not compare the costs of controllable and non-controllable energy.

Rule n ° 2: if one wants to compare the two, one includes the costs (financial and environmental) of storage for the non-controllable (hydrogen, WWTP, battery ... I let you choose)

Rule n ° 3: if one does not want to develop storage, one specifies the energy put in place as a back-up (hydro, gas, biomass?)

Rule n ° 4: if one consider that consumption adapts to production by demand response, then the service provided is less, so we refer to rule n ° 1.

I've been doing a course on sustainability and while on one hand it's clear that we need to make this shift ASAP, there are also so many problems with these renewable sources.
Hydropower is great but we're seeing problems with dams in river ecosystems, and from my understanding it doesn't have that much scope to expand.
Wind power too seems good but it requires so much space to set up windmills that simply isn't available in so many countries around the world.
Solar power thankfully seems to be getting cheaper and more efficient, but like with wind and hydro we're quite restricted to actually getting sun at the right time - how can we store and continue to use this energy year round?
With nuclear power, the waste aspect is less than ideal - and of course, knowing the scope for disasters and looking at cases like chernobyl just makes me worry that it's far from a perfect solution.
Even other "green" alternatives like biogas which may look like better options have such low energy returns that we're not even sure how efficient it is to use them.
My point being, it's far from a simple shift to one type of energy to another. We're also reliant on constant improvements in technology, balancing the various economic impacts of these methods, and proper safety when it comes to nuclear power. Additionally, we NEED to work on reducing our power usage in the first place - the top richest portion of the population uses far more energy than the rest of the world, and far more than they need to.

TL;DR - the green alternatives are better, but far from perfect, and still need work. We should be focusing on cutting down our energy consumption in the first place.

I love the idea of renewable energy. There was a study that showed that if even a small percentage of the Sahara was covered in solar, it would power all the energy needs of the entire world, though transportation of this energy is challenging, obviously. I do have a question, why is government required to do this? As you stated in the beginning, there have been 2 previous industrial revolutions. These leaps forward were not mandated by government bureaucrats or autocrats. They were due to the ingenuity of individuals and companies. I fear that, although renewable energy is clearly getting more affordable, too drastic of a push, mandated by law could, and likely would have a deleterious impact on the poorest in this country and others around the world. I agree with you that the tax system in the US and in many other places is inefficient, however, I believe that the cause is more related to the complexity of the system and the sheer number of loopholes than to a lack of incentive to tax the rich. I would argue that the better option would be to allow the market to determine the course for introducing and accelerating the use of renewable or clean energy. Even among environmentalists, there are disagreements on these types of energy generation technologies. Some are harmful to wildlife (wind and certain types of solar) or to the land itself (all of the above, but particularly hydroelectric, as the construction of a dam is generally required). Even wave energy conversion technology has been shown to be potentially dangerous. As Thomas Sowell has said, there are no solutions, merely trade-offs. What are we willing to sacrifice? Where do we place our value? The concern that exists to me is a select few in positions of government determining those values for the masses at a cost that is, as of yet, unknown. We may not be willing to pay the long-term costs (not necessarily monetary costs). California has one of the strongest road maps to renewable energy. It has diverted valuable resources of PG&E to renewable and away from updating and upgrading their infrastructure (power lines). These lines are decades old and have been the cause of over 1,500 California wildfires from 2012-2019 according to an article from the Business Insider last November. These types of resource mismanagement is what I fear will result from more government intervention. Suffice it to say, I hope we find a way to move towards a more efficient source of energy that is clean and safe, but voting for politicians to manage and mandate that move is short-sighted at best and extremely dangerous at worst, not only for the people impacted by it, but for the wildlife and the planet as a whole. I enjoyed your video, but I think the call to political action is concerning. Thank you.

7:46, you state that between the 1950s and 60s there was a marginal tax rate that maxed out at ~90%. This is true, however the Government still made just about the same amount of revenue that they make today. In the 1950s and 60s, the government made 17% of the country’s GDP off of taxes. Today the government makes guess how much? 17%. Still 17%. Between when the 90% marginal rate was abandoned to now, where there is a ~35% marginal tax rate, the government still made about 17% of the GDP in taxes.

The reason we make the same amount is because the government fixed the loopholes that many large business owners used to evade taxes in the 1950s and 60s. Although it was used on paper in the 1950s and 60s, they were easier to evade. Since those loopholes don’t exist anymore, it is almost certain that large business owners would move out of the US and conduct their business elsewhere. Here is a link to the graph of taxes collected as a % of GDP https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FYFRGDA188S

The amazon profit of 11.2 billion without paying taxes is an apples and oranges comparison. 11.2 billion in GAAP net income can be equivalent to 0 in IRS income depending on the size of amazon’s deferred tax assets at that time. And they had some hefty loss carryforwards from losing money early on contributing to large DTAs. You cannot compare two separate bases of accounting like you did for this reason.

You can, however, trust that the IRS always takes what’s theirs as the tax code is a robust system that has undergone decades of tweaks to snuff out any strange technicalities us accountants might try to find and exploit. Do they still exist? Probably. But audited corporations (ie Amazon) would have to disclose in their financial statements if they took any tax position that could be seen as “aggressive” by the IRS. The IRS will get their 21% of corporate net income (IRS basis) (35% rate back in 2018) no matter what.

You two put together some great content that is typically well thought out and researched, but next time you want to talk taxes, please ask a CPA friend first to make sure you aren’t making such drastic oversimplifications. Cheers!

This comment will be buried, but as someone involved in renewable energy, IMO nuclear is currently untenable. Research into higher efficiency energy models with minimized potential for human error and accidents are fantastic, but like, that doesn't remove the issue of waste, or very justified public concern over safety.

The biggest problem with nuclear is the waste. It's highly radioactive, with few places that are geologically stable enough to store it for millions of years, and no one wants it near them. Part of that is from a place of environmental justice, where the history of nuclearism is very deeply tied to nuclear weapons, but also that uranium mining and waste storage has pretty much always negatively impacted marginalized groups (RECA is still inadequate and doesn't cover all people affected, I highly recommend looking into the Tularosa Basin Downwinders Association).

Like, in the USA the Navajo Nation has well over 500 abandoned uranium mines, with large swathes of land contaminated. As a result, surrounding states have zero interest in waste storage. Yucca Mountain had massive issues, both politically and also simply with the plan being pushed through without a full review of its scientific legitimacy. The same thing is happening in New Mexico with WIPP and the proposed Holtec site. In the USA as well as basically every country with nuclear energy, waste is hoisted onto rural, low-income, often indigenous peoples.

Nuclear has enormous potential, but imo currently the issues with it are insurmountable as few people actually want to constructively discuss them. It's frustrating, particularly because as someone in STEM I constantly see my peers condescend to and dismiss people who are concerned or critical of nuclear energy, and deem them anti-science or simply stupid when every anti-nuclear activist I've talked to has been scientifically literate. :/

First, I support the entire idea here about moving to renewables and moving quickly, no question. That said, I'd encourage some deeper thought and analysis in how to best pay for it.

In particular, I'd encourage @asapscience to dig into the familiar refrain of, "Amazon doesn't pay any taxes!!!" I think it'd be a valuable thing for you and your audience to understand. It's not some love affair with Amazon (I'm pretty sure there is no love between Donald Trump and Jeff Besos.

For one, a huge part of what offsets Amazon's tax bill is a thing called carryforward losses. What's that? Amazon went years, losing billions of dollars a year to build up businesses that now employ more than a million people. After they're incurred, these losses can be used to offset future tax bills.

Why is this good? Well, it encourages businesses to make bigger, longer term bets, and not just playing things year-to-year. And, in the end, that ends up benefiting the company, the additional employees it's able to employ and governments ability to pay for stuff with it's larger tax base.

There's more, like allowing companies to make deductions for R&D, which Amazon does too. That's not to say all tax cuts/deductions are good or smart, they're not, but like many things, there's a lot more nuance to this conversation. Something that I'd imagine you @asapscience guys and your followers would appreciate. Thanks.

The main thing holding renewable back is storage.  Wind is unpredictable, and solar produces a bell curve of energy throughout the day, and no energy at night.  This means to go fully renewable, you HAVE to have storage.  Batteries suck -- they have horrible energy density, and require mining out lots of material to produce, not to mention the problem of recycling the old ones.  There are alternatives to batteries for storage, but they each have their own problems as well.  For the record, I love renewable energy and cant wait to see it take over.

Interesting facts! Let me play the devil's advocate here for a moment.

Not really sure however that renewables will meet our current and future energy needs given most of the world's current energy consumption come from fossil fuels (about 80% if I am not mistaken). You also say that building renewables is cheap today. That is certainly true, but I think you forget the fact that it is cheap only thanks to the energy fossil fuels give us in order to build those renewables. It will another story when you'll have to build (extracting metals, assembling, transporting, etc) wind turbines just from the energy of wind turbines... And let's not forget that building renewables is itself far from being environmental friendly at the moment...

One last thing is that, although the internet of things certainly can be more energy efficient, let's not forget about the rebound effect which tells us that an increase in a technology's efficiency often comes with a greater use of this technology, negating the benefits we thought we had by it becoming more efficient. In other words, although more efficient, the IoTs will use exponentially more connected devices interacting with one another, which could increase the total system's energy use instead of decreasing it. For the moment (because fossil fuels give us most of our energy), more energy used = more CO2 emissions.

Conclusion: not sure putting all our effort in renewables and IoT is best for the planet. Maybe we should put priority on reviewing our fundamental needs and question our current energy consumption.

I agree with most of what you are saying however your saying it in a very misleading way. For instance "if we just used 1% of the energy that comes from the sun" it sounds low but in reality that's nearly 2 million square miles assuming that your solar panels are 100% efficient.

I am an actual scientist from the energy sector who has directed programs over $1 B. The companies I worked for had no affiliation with any fossil fuels and included all alternatives such as nuclear, wind, hydro, solar, and storage (all at the same company). I also worked at a second international nuclear company and the 2nd largest wind generation company. With over $1M per day in generation, the company would have invested in any option that improved the bottom line and constancy of generation. There are no more significant hydro opportunities. Solar (even with land already owned) was not economically viable. Wind was only viable under heavy subsidy and was terminated after one installation as not economically viable. The wind farm model has been proven much more expensive and with bigger impacts than what was suggested just a few years ago. Many sit idle due to curtailment or have been built under subsidies only to sit idle because they are not connected to the grid. The "green" experiment in Germany has resulted in massive power cost increases while other countries such as France have a much more successful model.

Power has to be a mix and I support continued development but the green options are ALL MUCH MORE EXPENSIVE. Wind has a few places where it can be expanded. Put solar on your house if you want. The difference between coal and natural gas emissions is small. The US has a stockpile of usable nuclear material we all paid for during the cold war and we should use it in small modular reactors. Final FYI - "spent" fuel rods from old reactors are 94% unused uranium but it is not legal to re-refine it.

Germany isn't really the shining example for this. While it is true that Germany is shrinking their coal industry while expanding wind and solar they have also stated that they will decommission ALL of their nuclear power plants as part of their energy plan. To replace the stable baseload power generated by nuclear Germany has opted to use natural gas, thus resulting in a net increase in greenhouse gas emission from Germany since the start of their new energy initiatives.

France is a far better example where ~80% of power in France is generated by nuclear power with the majority of the remaining 20% being generated by wind and solar. The result is a power grid that has the lowest emissions per capita in Europe and lower cost per KWhr compared to Germany (which has also seen an increase in cost per KWhr since the implementation of their new energy initiatives).
